Fatalities split between five events.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Mali (2013-2020)
column16: Reuters; Undisclosed Source; Jeune Afrique; AMAP
column17: On 18 August 2020, national guards conducted a coup d'etat and took control of the military camp in N'Tominkorobougou in the capital of Bamako (Bamako, Bamako). The soldiers arrested President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita, Prime Minister Boubou Cisse and other senior officials, and transferred them to the military camp in Kati. President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita announced his resignation, dissolved the national assembly and the government in a broadcast on state-owned television ORTM while detained. The following day in Kati, the soldiers announced the establishment of the National Committee for the Salvation of the People (CNSP), and vowed a transition to civilian rule, hold elections within a reasonable timeframe, maintain military cooperation with international forces present in Mali, and uphold the 2015 Algiers Accord peace agreement. A nightly curfew and the closure of land and aerial borders were also declared.

On 18 August 2020, French Operation Barkhane forces conducted a ground operation against presumed ISGS militants in the area of Tamalat (Menaka, Gao). The French soldiers carried out arrests and recovered equipment.

They briefly held a staff member hostage who was released following the intervention of the gendarmerie. [size=about 100]

JNIM claimed responsibility via Al Qaeda-linked Thabat News Agency and said it killed 15 soldiers, wounded 3, and destroyed 4 tank trucks and 2 vehicles. Neither the 20 militants ""neutralized"" by the Malian army nor the higher death toll in the ranks of the Malian army communicated by Thabat News Agency could be independently verified.

Unknown assailants failed to abduct a European employee of the International Committee Red Cross (ICRC) in the Mauritanian capital Nouakchott, said a report by Mauritanian news agency Al-Akhbar on 19 December.
Six Mauritanian anti-slavery militants have been charged with assaulting security forces during a demonstration to demand the release of two girls held in bondage, a judicial source said Monday.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Three armed members of Al-Qaidah Maghreb escaped arrest by presidential security guards last night following extensive fire exchange that lasted almost an hour. column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Mauritanian policeman was killed Thursday night by two members of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQMI) in the region of Legsseiba, near the north bank of the River Senegal.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Detonation: A suspected al-Qaida militant killed himself by detonating an explosive belt to avoid capture in Lexeiba as security forces arrested his alleged accomplice in connection with an explosion earlier in the week.

Police in Mauritania used ""excessive"" force to disperse young activists who were trying to stage an anti-government protest in a square in the centre of the capital, a Mauritanian journalist told Al-Jazeera TV on 11 March.
Mauritanian police cracked down on protests against water shortages and rising prices in the south-eastern town of Vassal, an opposition party said Saturday.
Hundreds of people took to the streets in Mauritania on Friday calling for better living conditions and more jobs.

Police dispersed 200 to 300 young protesters in the early morning of Saturday (26 February) in the Mauritanian capital Nouakchott. The anti-government demonstration had started the day before in a central square.

Text of report by Mauritanian independent news agency Al-Akhbar website Ablokat Square, the centre of the Mauritanian capital Nouakchott, was this evening the scene of a youth protest demanding political and economic reform in the country.
Mauritanian police on Tuesday stopped dozens of youths from rallying in a central Nouakchott square amid calls for political and economic reforms, an AFP journalist saw.

On 26 March, independent Mauritanian news agency Al-Akhbar reported on its website that Protesters and journalists in Nouakchott had been ""attacked"" by national police forces last night, Friday 25 March.

Security forces using teargas and batons dispersed several hundred anti-government protesters in the Mauritanian capital Nouakchott on Monday, the most serious clash in the West African state for nearly two months.
Dozens of young Mauritanians are holding a sit-in outside the police directorates office to demand the release of 20 protesters arrested the previous day.
About 20 Mauritanian youths detained after anti-riot police broke up a protest against President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz were freed on Wednesday, a local news website reported.
Thousands of Mauritanian workers marched in May Day rallies in Nouakchott on Sunday, demanding better working conditions and higher salaries to offset soaring food costs.
Several were arrested on Thursday after fresh clashes erupted between rival student groups at the University of Nouakchott, witnesses reported.
Some 30 Mauritanian women, members of the Salafist branch of Islam, denounced the ""assassination"" of Osama bin Laden om a demonstration in Nouakchott Sunday.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Mauritanian security forces shot dead a suspected member of al Qaedas North African wing and captured another after a firefight in the countries remote desert late last week, the army said. ""One of our patrols intercepted a Toyota Land Cruiser with two suspects 200 kilometres (120 miles) north of Lemgheity,"" according to an army statement issued on Tuesday, a translation of which was obtained by Reuters on Wednesday.Mauritanian security forces shot dead a suspected member of al Qaedas North African wing and captured another after a firefight in the countries remote desert late last week, the army said.

Nouakchott (Mauritania) Mauritania Justice Minister, Abidine Ould Kheir has for the first time acknowledged that 13 Salafist militants who were convicted and detained at a prison in Nouakchott had been transferred to an undisclosed location. The families of the prisoners had earlier held sit-in demonstrations in the capital Nouakchott in a bid to extract more information on their whereabouts.

Tens of members of the revolutionary committees in Mauritania have demonstrated in front of the Qatari embassy in Nouakchott shouting hostile slogans against the State of Qatar and its emir Shaykh Hamad Bin-Khalifah Al Thani on account of his stances in support of the Libyan revolutionaries.

Dozens of journalists engaged in a sit-in outside the Mauritanian Public Agency (AMI) to demand their rights and a wage increase.
Dozens of journalists engaged in a sit-in outside the Radio Mauritania building, following a sit-in earlier this week, to demand raised wages.
Hundreds protested and blocked the road leading from Rosso to Nouakchott, demanding clean water.
Dozens of women protested to support mining workers who are on strike.

Hundreds protested in front of the Ministry of Justice to denounce ""hateful and racist"" words of former senator Sidi Ould Dahi who claimed that oppression of black Mauritanians from 1989-1992 was appropriate.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: Tens of thousands marched in Nouakchott to support the ongoing strike of SNIM workers in Zouerate and Nouadhibou.

Protesters threw stones at the presidents convoy as he traveled through Zouerat. A Mauritanian TV camerman was hit, and at least one citizen was beaten by police who used batons to disperse the protest.
Protesters ""accosted"" President Mohamed Ould Abdelaziz as he was leaving a visit to the Guerou hospital. Security tried to disperse the protesters, but the President allowed them to speak with him.
Thousands of descendants of slaves marched in protest of discrimination and marginalization.

column7: UTM: Union of Workers of Mauritania
column17: Workers held a rally for international Labor Day, led by local Unions.
Dozens protested in conjunction with the arrival of President Abdelaziz to the Dar al-Barak area. At least four were arrested when the security forces dispersed them.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: Anti-slavery activists held a sit-in in the town of Aleg and several were then arrested in nearby Rosso.
Dozens of former employees of the french company PIZZORNO protested to demand payments.

column7: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
column17: Hundreds of anti-slavery activists held a sit-in in front of the National Assembly, protesting the detention of two activists.

A demonstration was taken out by activists of the 25 February movement against an alleged rape by a ""road security man"". 2 of the activists were arrested during the protest (specific location not given).

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: 100 IRA anti-slavery protesters in Nouakchott demand release of their leader and one of his aides who were arrested. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse protesters, injuring 6. 23 arrested.
A Malian military unit was reportedly responsible for killing a merchant and injuring another in Mauritanian territory in ""the east"" near the border with Mali.
Sit-ins took place in Nouakchott in tandem with those in the east protesting government inaction after Malian forces killed a merchant.
""Angry protests"" led to the closure of a weekly market as demonstrators have been staging protests ""for days"" due to government silence over the recent killing of a merchant by Malian forces.
Soldiers from military unit 7 attacked the security center in the Brakna region ""to avenge a comrade"" who had been beaten by members of Brigade 4. A number of those soldiers were arrested.
An imam led a protest against ""confiscation"" of a public square in front of a mosque and was arrested.
Several were arrested while protesting outside fo the Saudi embassy, claiming ill treatment of Mauritanian Harati women in Saudi Arabia.
Dozens protested to decry human rights violations against Haratine women working in Saudi Arabia.
Dozens of protesters, mostly youth, held a sit in against the Ministry of Healths inaction against a recent fever epidemic.
Demonstrators protested in front of the Health Ministry against ""the deteriorating health situation""

column6: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
column17: Authorities claim members of the IRA kidnapped and tortured a young girl. IRA leaders deny involvement.
Police arrested several students who were protesting poor transportation at the University of Nouakchott.
Families of Salafi prisoners protested outside the jail.

column8: Police Forces of Mauritania (2009-) Prison Guards
column17: At least 40 prisoners escaped after attacking a guard.
Dozens of journalists protested against suspension of television show.

column7: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement; Journalists (Mauritania)
column17: Members of the Initiative for the Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement, IRA-Mauritania have ""besieged"" anti-riot police mini buses in capital Nouakchott. the activists of IRA - an anti-slavery group - shown in the photo standing in front of a ""police"" mini-bus were stopping it and ""chanting hostile slogans against the regime of President Mohamed Ould Abdelaziz"", while the mini-buses lined up behind were waiting to be allowed by IRA activists to continue driving. Police arrested a journalist covering the demonstration.

column7: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
column17: Police used tear gas, batons, and stun grenades to disperse anti-slavery protesters holding a sit-in to demand the release of imprisoned activists.
Thousands marched in favor of the rights of former slaves and descendants of slaves.
Unionists marched to commemorate Labor Day and demand increased benefits and decreased prices.
Police forcibly dispersed protesters marching towards Russian embassy to protest bombings in Syria.
Several protesters of the Mauritanian opposition demonstrated against the revision of the constitution announced on May the 3rd by the President Mohamend Ould Abdel Aziz.
Youth protested in front of the national security office to demand increased stability.

column7: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
column17: Police clashed with anti-slavery activists as the government attempted to relocate the slum where they lived. At least five IRA leaders arrested and seven police injured.

Arrests: The day after clashes between rioters and police, security forces used tractors to ""displace"" residents and their belongings in a primarily Haratine slum. Arrests may have continued into this day.

column7: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
column17: Police dispersed a demonstration with teargas on Monday in Nouakchott where anti-slavery activists protesting against recent arrests in their ranks.

column6: Police Forces of Mauritania (2009-) Prison Guards
column9: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement; Prisoners (Mauritania)
column17: 13 anti-slavery activists who were arrested in Nouakchott in July 2016 claim they were tortured in prison.

column7: TPN: Dont Touch My Nationality; Students (Mauritania)
column17: Several dozen activists of the TPN movement staged a sit-in outside the offices of the Department of Justice in Nouakchott to demand action against a police officer who allegedly killed a student in Maghama in 2011.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: After police prevented them from marching, IRA ativists staged a sit-in in solidarity with 13 IRA activists who were arrested and jailed in June after violent protests over the dismantling of a slum of Nouakchott.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: Thousands of people marched in Nouakchott before ending up for a rally in the city center, the call of the National Forum for Unity and Democracy (FNDU), a coalition of a dozen parties of the radical opposition.
Strike to protest against a reform of the activity in the port of Nouakchott. Thirty dockers were arrested on Monday after clashes with security forces.
The Mauritanian forces violently dispersed a demonstration in the Port of Nouakchott. Around 20 people arrested while police used tear gas and batons.

Hundreds protested Tuesday in Mauritania calling for a blogger convicted of ""infidel"" behaviour to be executed. Cheikh Ould Mohamed Ould Mkheitir was initially sentenced to death for apostasy in 2014 over a blog post deemed insulting to the Prophet Mohammed.
The police used tear gas to disperse a manifestation of individuals demanding the execution of Mohamed Ould MKheitir, a blogger sentenced to death for ""apostasy"" in 2015.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: A large gathering of opposition members from the FNDU, RFD and UNAD parties in Nouakchott denounced the ""looting of national resources"" and mismanagement by the government. 8 youths involved in the protest were arrested.
Mauritanian police dispersed a demonstration demanding the death sentence for a young blogger accused of blasphemy. The several hundred protesters were dispersed with tear gas.
""Future Engineers"" Association protested in front of the parliament to call for supporting their demands, amongs others creating jobs for the unemployed engineers.
Dozens of journalists, rights activists and MPs protested in Nouakchott to call for the release of an Al Jazeera journalist detained in Egypt.
Thousands of people protested in Nouakchott to demand the execution of a blogger convicted of apostasy.
4 Mauritanians were kidnapped in the Mbeiket area near the border with Mali, allegedly by pro-Bamako militiamen.

Police dispersed a protest of the opposition in Nouakchott with tear gas and batons. The opposition activists were protesting against proposed constitutional reforms being considered by the parliament.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity, RFD: Rally of Democratic Forces
column17: Tens of thousands of people marched in Nouakchoot on the call of the FNDU and RFD against proposed constitutional reforms that were approved by the Mauritanian legislature.

Workers at the Indian Quartz company, that extracts quartz mineral in Mauritania, protested against unpaid wages. Workers said that they have taken all the steps in order to get their dues over the last two months but the company ignored them. Workers said that they will continue to strike until they get paid.
Sewage worked protested in front of the presidential palace in Nouakchott to demand that they finally receive their salaries that are 6 months overdue.
A Mauritanian soldier and another person were killed and one person wounded in the Riyadh suburb of Nouakchott after an armed explosive was found on the roadside. Another explosive was defused.
A number of teachers protested against the non-payment of salaries, being overdue more than 4 months.

Police allegedly violently dispersed a peaceful march in Nouakchott, arresting several demonstrators and injuring several. The march was organized to protest against youth marginalization, unemployment, and bad standard of living. 10 of those present were arrested.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: The anti-slavery 'Initiative for the Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement' organized a protest in the streets of Nouakchott to commemorate former slaves and protest against current forms of slavery. The police intervened and used teargas to disperse the protesters, entering into confrontation with some of them.

column7: UTM: Union of Workers of Mauritania
column16: Agence Mauritanienne d'Information; PANAPRESS; RFI; ATUC
column17: Miners marched in Nouakchott and launched from the following day a 24h nationwide strike action to call for better salaries and employment conditions by SNIM - the National Society for the Mining Industry. On the same day, UTM led a march in Nouakchott, calling for reduced consumer good prices, increased salaries and tax suppression.

Taxi drivers protested against new road regulations for two consecutive days in Nouakchott. They burnt tyres on roads in various parts of the capital, blocking traffic, threw rocks on property, and clashed with police, who fired teargas to disperse them. Several people were injured and important material damage recorded.

Taxi drivers protested against new road regulations for two consecutive days in Nouakchott. They burnt tyres on roads in various parts of the capital, blocking traffic, threw rocks on property, and clashed with police, who fired teargas to disperse them. Several people were injured and important material damage recorded.

column9: SIPES: Independent Union of Secondary Education Teachers
column17: Security forces violently suppressed a peaceful protest organized by the Secondary Education Teacher Union in Nouakchott. This act by police sparked criticism among activists. The union condemned the police's use of ""brutal"" and ""cowardly"" violence against the protesting professors in front of the buildings of the Ministry of National Education.
The Mauritanian Congress for the Upholding of National Unity organized a demonstration in support of the constitutional amendments that will be put to referendum on 15 July.
Technical and vocational training teachers protested against the non-payment of some of the teachers' allowances.
Workers at the Central electric station of 'Snim' company in Azuirat city protested in response to the failure of the company to pay a bonus that they used to receive in May each year.
Several thousand Mauritanians attended a demonstration in Nouakchott to protest the referendum planned for 5 August.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.
Activists held a peaceful protest in Rosso where they chanted slogans against the constitutional referendum. A number of them were arrested.
Activists held a peaceful protest in Nouakchott, where they distributed flyers and chanted slogans against the constitutional referendum. 3 were arrested by the police.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.
The Mauritanian police used tear gas and baton sticks to violently disperse a protest against the constitutional referendum in Arafat. Several wounded.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement. On the same day different demonstrations and shows of forces took place in different areas and suburbs of Nouakchott, organized by the government, in order to garner support for the constitutional referendum.

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

Mauritanian senators held a sit-in at the institution's premises in Nouakchott on Wednesday afternoon to protest against the proposed constitutional revision, which foresees the abolition of the senate

""Protests have been taking place daily since 21 July, led by opposition politicians calling for a boycott of the vote,"" said Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), in a statement.

Police and opposition activists clashed Thursday in Mauritania's capital on the final day of campaigning for a controversial constitutional referendum. The authorities refused to give the green light for protests opposing the constitutional changes in Nouakchott and three regions of the west African country, leading to what activists said was ""excessive"" use of tear gas in an area to the west of the capital, which caused some people to faint. Around 20 senators maintained a sit-in at the chamber on Thursday, under police guard. Opposition lawmakers from the lower house have followed suit in solidarity with their peers, a parliamentary source told AFP.

Arrests: The governor of Tidjikja province had arrested all bakery workers in the city due to their strike which they started a week ago. Bakers entered the strike to protest against preventing them from increasing the price of the bread to 40 ougya, an increase of 10 ougya.
Workers protested in front of the old youth house in Nouadhibou to demand their rights after one month and 15 days of strike in the city.

Journalists staged a sit-in in front of the National Directory of Security in Nouakchott. They protest against the confiscation of passports from some colleagues and tracking of their professional activities.

Former senators tried to hold an improvised session in the former senate but were prevented and chased away by police forces. Reminder that the senate has been abolished by popular referendum around one month ago.

Former senators tried to hold an improvised session in the former senate but were prevented and chased away by police forces. Reminder that the senate has been abolished by popular referendum around one month ago.

Several gold miners in Tiris Zemmour, in Mauritania's north, were injured when a military helicopter inadvertently fired at them on the morning of 26 September. The helicopter was chasing a group of smugglers who then got mixed in between the miners.
Mauritanian activists from the Movement for the Change of the Constitution have staged a protest against a newly announced anthem in the capital Nouakchott.
Police dispersed a protest organized by a number of the dissolved Mauritanian Senate's members in the capital Nouakchott.
Dozens of workers of the Chinese fishing company Poly Hon Done demonstrated in Nouakchott after the company arbitrarily dismissed them. Protesters calledon the authorities to intervene.
There have been nationwide protests against a lenient verdict that was issued by the court of appeal in Nouadhibou against a blogger accused of apostasy.

A protest by radical Islamists in Nouakchott against the light sentence of two years prison for the liberal blogger, Mohamed Ould m'Khetir, was dispersed by police forces with teargas and truncheons. Several protesters were injured.
Hundreds of people in the eastern city of Laayoune went to the streets to condemn the alleged light sentence (two years prison and no death penalty) handed down against a liberal blogger.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: Opposition parties have held a protest rally to pressure President Ould Abdel Aziz not to run for a third term in elections in 2019. They accuse him of succumbing to Western pressure over reducing the sentence for a blogger accused of apostasy from the death penalty to a two-years sentence.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: Opposition parties have held a protest rally to pressure President Ould Abdel Aziz not to run for a third term in elections in 2019. They accuse him of succumbing to Western pressure over reducing the sentence for a blogger accused of apostasy from the death penalty to a two-years sentence.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement; Women (Mauritania)
column17: A group of widows and orphans from those killed by the military regime in the 1990s disrupt the independence day celebrations and call for an inquiry into forced disappearances. They are arrested by the police.
Hundreds of Mauritanians protested in the capital Nouakchott against US president Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital.

Mauritanian lawyers held a rally in the capital Nouakchott on 13 December over the US decision to recognise Jerusalem as Israel's capital and called on the OIC summit in Turkey ""to take decisions that serve the Palestinian cause seriously"" and adopt a ""clearer"" stand on the issue.

Mauritanian police has arrested protesters who carried the old flag of the country, which was abolished in November, during a rally held in Nouakchott. Five of them were later handed prison sentences.
Workers of the National Road Maintenance Company (ENER) in Nouakchott protested to call on the government's to pay their delayed salaries.
Workers from the Mauritanian company ""Sonimex"" for import and export protested in front of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry against corruption and misconduct in their company.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: Members from the IRA, an anti-slavery movement, organized a protest march in Nouakchott to call for the release of two activists being jailed since 2016.

Mauritanian journalists have held a sit in in their offices in Nouakchott to demand the release by the Egyptian authorities of their fellow journalist Mahmoud Hussein who worked for al-Jazeera. On the same day, the parliamentary Palestinian support group organised a protest in front of the US embassy in Nouakchott to denounce the recent decision of the US to recognize Jerusalem as Israels capital and move it's embassy there.
Unemployed medical workers organised a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Health in Nouakchott to call on the government to provide them with jobs.
Fishermen protested in Nouakchott to protest against new administrative measures that prevent them from accessing the sea from some places.

column9: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity; IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: The FNDU and the IRA organised a protest in Nouakchott to protest against rising prices, high costs of living and low salaries. Protesters were reportedly violently attacked by police leading to several injured. At least 7 protesters were arrested.
Police forces violently dispersed a student sit-in in Nouakchott. Several protesters were severely injured.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: IRA activists protested against the rise in the prices of basic goods and high costs of living. Protesters were injured by police forces.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: IRA activists protested against the rise in the prices of basic goods and high costs of living. Protesters were injured by police forces.

column9: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: Mauritanian human rights activists have said that the country's police used batons and tear gas to disperse their protest in capital Nouakchott yesterday, 20 February, injuring ""dozens"" of them and arresting 12, including their leader.
""Amal program"" workers carried out a protest in Nouakchott, asking for a contract of employment with the Labour court.
Protesters gathered in front of the presidential palace in Nouakchott to call on incumbent president Ould Abd-el-Aziz to compete in the upcoming elections.
On 11 March Mauritanian police forces violently dispersed a protest by students who called for lowering the age to be eligible for scholarships from 25 to 22 years. Several students were injured.

On 18 March, dozens of workers protested in front of ENER national road maintenance company against the dismissal of 127 workers during a fusion with ATTM company. Police forces ended the protest through threatening to use force.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: On 26 March, opposition actors from the FNDU organised a sit-in in front of the general directorate of national security in Nouakchott to denounce repression measures against Mauritanian ex-senators. The senate has been dissolved after a popular vote last year.
On 3 April, a number of 'Amal'-program workers protested in front of the offices of the Food Security Commission in Nouakchott to calll for a payment of salaries and proper distribution of food.

column7: TPMC: Do Not Touch My Constitution Platform
column17: On 5 April, young activists from the movement 'Don't touch my constitution' organised a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Health in Nouakchott to denounce counterfeit and expired pharmaceutical products.
On 1 May, workers in Nouadhibou protested, condemning high prices and low salaries, during the celebration of International Workers Day.

On 4 May, harratine Mauritanians protested on the streets of Noaukchott against slavery in the framework of the fourth anniversary of the Haratines manifesto, denouncing ongoing discrimination against the black Mauritanians.
On 9 May, Mauritanian gold prospectors staged a protest in the city of Chami to demand taxes to be reduced for the exploration of gold.
On 10 May, dozens of residents of the city of Tidjikja in central Mauritania protested in front of the Presidential Palace, in the capital Noukchoutt, over the problem of water shortage in the city.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: On 13 May, thousands of members from the oppositional FNDU staged a protest in Nouakchott to call for the dissolution of the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI) which they consider corrupt.

column9: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: Arrests: On 14 May, Mauritanian police searched the homes of well-known businessmen Boumatou and Debbagh who are known to support FNDU opposition senator Mohamed Ould Ghada. Police also temporarily detained Boutamou's son and the wife of Debbagh. The government accuses them of trying to destabilize the regime.

On 28 May, Amal welfare program workers protested in front of the HQs of the Food Security Commission to denounce mismanagement by the program coordinator. The coordinator subsequently recorded adresses from the protesters and blackmailed them.
On 4 June several dozen of professors from the Institute of Islamic Research (ISERI) protested in front of the national assembly to denounce injustices that they suffer from, primarily low salaries.

Defection: On 4 June an officer in Mauritania's air force, Ould Brahim, deserted and appealed for asylum in Belgium. In a video circulated online on 4 June the deserted officer critisises the rampant corruption and racism prevalent in the Mauritanian military and the deterioration of salaries.

On 5 June hundreds of medical workers who are on strike for more than a month protested in front of the National Hospital (CHN) in Nouakchott. Protesters call for a raise in salaries and the adoption of a special legal status for medical workers.

On 6 June workers of the national printing press organised a protest in front of the presidential palace in Nouakchott, the National Assembly building and the Ministry of Communication to ask for the payment of their delayed salaries.
On 11 July, workers at the Moroccan Mauritanian telecoms company 'Mauritel' launched a protest in the Nouakchott HQs. They ask for a regulation and improvement of their socio-professional situation.

On 18 July, a number of fishermen and family members protested outside state offices in Nouadhibou, demanding government measures to protect them and their small fishing boats in light of recurrent collisions with large vessels that had led to deaths.

On 27 July, Mauritanians blocked the main road 34km northwest of Rosso with burning tires and pieces of wood over the lack of drinking water during a heatwave coupled with the prolonged drought that has been affecting the country for months now. Gendarmerie intervened to end the protest.
On 30 July, Mauritanian police used tear gas and sound bombs to disperse a protest march by Nouakchott port porters and chased them in the streets of Arafat in Nouakchott. No injuries were reported.

column9: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: Arrests: On 6 August, opposition figure and leader of the IRA movement, Biram Ould Dah Ouled Abeid has been arrested, one week after Mohamad Ould Cheikh, a journalist and University of Qatar media professor, had been arrested. No reasons for arrests have been given but Ould Abed was due to participate in the upcoming parliamentary elections on 1 September.

On 9 August, Mauritanian journalists staged a protest outside a police station in Nouakchott where two journalists, Babacar N'Diaye (editor in chief of Cridem) and Mahmoud Ouled Saibout (Taqadoumy) were kept after having been arrested over an article about the lawyer Gamal Ould Mohamed.

On 10 August, unidentified militants attacked a Mauritanian patrol in the North-East near the border with Mali. Two assailants were killed, two others and two soldiers were injured and one military vehicle destroyed.
On 13 August, journalists staged a sit-in in front of a police commissariat in Nouakchott to call for the liberation of their colleague Ndiyae and Saibout who have been arrested last week.

Non-violent activity: On 1 September, well-known opposition senator Mohamed Ould Ghadda who had been in detention for over a year has been liberated. He is now prosecuted for 'spreading corruption'. Ould Ghadda was one of the main figures denouncing the abolition of the senate after a referendum in 2017.

column7: FNDU: National Forum for Democracy and Unity
column17: On 4 September, opposition figures around the FNDU protested in front of the CENI (electoral commission) HQs in Nouakchott to denounce the delay in publication of electoral results and potential irregularities/fraud. Legislative, regional and municipal elections took place last Sunday. FNDU later had a meeting with the CENI.

On October 1st, opposition MPs gathered outside the parliament in Nouakchott, to protest against the continued detenion of the IRA founding politician and activist, Ould Abeid. Note that this was one of two separate protests calling for his release.

column9: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: On or before October 1st, police violently dispersed a protest by IRA members, who were disgruntled at the continued detention of their founder, Ould Abeid. Police used batons and stun grenades against the protesters. The protest seems to have taken place in Nouakchott. Another protest by MPs agiant Abeid's detenton occurred in Nouakchott on the same day.

On or before October 3rd, students and academics gathered in Nouakchott to protest against the closure of two Islamic higher education institutes by the authorities, allegedly due to links between these institutes and the Islamic political opposition, as well as the Muslim Brotherhood. Two academics were arrested by police.

column9: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: On October 8th, activists with the IRA movement gathered outside the parliament in Nouakchott as MPs were electing a new Speaker for the assembly, to protest against the continued detenion of the IRA founding politician and activist, Ould Abeid. Police dispersed the protest using tear gas and stun grenades.
On October 8th, police forces beat and detained a photo journalist covering protests outside the parliament in Nouakchott.

On or before October 11th, police used force to disperse protesters demonstrating in Nouakchott. The demonstrators were protesting against the closure of an Islamic education institute (following from a similar demonstration the previous week).
On October 18th, students once again protested the closure of an Islamic education institute in Nouakchott (which had been closed in late September).

On Oct 25, dozens of workers from the national printing press took to the streets in front of the presidential palace in the capital Nouakchott, asking for their salaries, which had reportedly not been paid for over four months.

On Nov 13, students in Selibaby protested alongside their parents to denounce the lack of infrastructures and teachers in the city's high school. Police intervened to disperse the protest and arrested a number of protesters.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: On Nov 22, a number of IRA militants took to the streets of Nouakchott to call for the release of IRA leader Biram Dah Ould Abeid, who has been detained since August 13 for allegedly assaulting a journalist. Police intervened with batons and tear gas to disperse the protest but no casualties were reported.

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
column17: 28 November. A march by a collective of widows, supported by the IRA, was stopped by police forces before the protesters reached the United Nations office in Nouakchott. Protesters marched for justice for victims of executions between September 1990 and February 1991.
29 November. Students protested against the visit of Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Bin Salman in Nouakchott
29 November. Students of the Centre for the Formation of Ulama protested at the Ministry of Islamic Affairs in Nouakchott and demanded the re-opening of their school
29 November. Workers protested in Nouakchott against the influence of Moroccans in their telecommunications company MORITEL
30 November. During Friday prayers in Nouakchott a student initiative organized protests against the visit of Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Ben Salman
On 1 December, students and human rights activists defied the government and protested the visit of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.
On 3 December, thousands of fishermen protested in front of the old youth house in Nouakchott, asking for the protection of fishing prices, fearing the recurrence of the dramatic 2008 scenario.

column16: El Mouritany; Cridem; Sahara Press Service
column17: On 7 December, a tribal conflict overhousing in Tiguent, mostly between women, led to the death of 1 girl of 7 years and others injured. The dispute began when a woman wanted to build a house in a village near Tikkun, but villagers denied it, arguing that the land she was planning to build had been sold to by her to them.
On 9 December, unemployed doctors protested in Nouakchott to call on the government to employ them in public hospitals.

column7: Teachers (Mauritania); SLEM: Free Union of Mauritanian Teachers
column17: On 12 Decembers, teachers from the Free Union of Mauritanian Teachers (SLEM) protested against what they consider verbal assaults on teachers in different schools.
On 13 December, unemployed doctors protested in front of the presidential palace in Nouakchott to call on the government to employ them in public hospitals.

column9: AJD-MR: Alliance for Justice and Democracy-Movement for Renewal

column7: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement

This came during a standstill for women activists in front of the National Assembly to demand legislation to protect them, after the rejection of the draft law for the second time.

Security forces detain three suspected of plotting terror attacks. Affiliation unknown. The group was suspected to use the Internet to plan acts of sabotage involving the use of car bombs both inside and outside the country.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Arrests: Moroccan security forces dismantled a militant group consisting of 27 members, among them a member of Al-Qaidah in the Lands of Islamic Maghreb, AQLIM. The group had sent the AQLIM member ""to establish a base in the kingdom and prepare a plan to carry out militant operations."" The security operation also resulted in the ""discovery of a cache of weapons in three sites in Emghala, 220 km from Laayoune.""
A group of Moroccan citizens and lawyers demonstrated outside and inside the Casablanca courtroom chanting slogans against the detention of Saharawi activists.

Unemployed university graduates staged a demonstration on 15 January in front of the Parliament building in Rabat. They called for freezing the draft law stipulating the abolition of the ministerial decisions on the immediate employment of university graduates.

In areas such as Chichaouah and Taroudent, local governors intervened to contain protest marches about subsidized flour not reaching the social groups they are destined to. No mention of police deployment.

A man protests his rejection from the army by public suicide by fire. .
About 200 Moroccans rallied in Rabat on 11 February, loudly cheering the toppling of former Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak while calling for reforms in the Arab world.

The protesters have taken a queue from protests in Egypt.

Regime protesters enter a customs building and take quantities of confiscated drugs and alcohol.

The foreign dead included Britons and French. 20 others were injured. Authorities believe AQIM is responsible, as the blast bore hallmarks of their work.

Members of families of Sahrawi prisoners arrested in November 2010 in El Ayun after the dismantling of Gdeim Izik camp by Moroccan forces rallied Tuesday in Rabat. The rally, observed by some thirty persons, mostly women, aims at demanding either the release of Sahrawi prisoners or the rapid organization of a fair trial, improving their conditions of incarceration and claiming the rights for visits extended to anyone other than family members.

Police violently dispersed protest marches in Agadir. Many were arrested and injured. Protesters were calling for political reform and greater democracy as well as the high cost of living and lack of jobs.

Police in Rabat used force to disperse doctors protesting to demand health reform. The protest was authorized, 40 doctors suffered various injuries, doctors demands are not political, they seek health reform, not regime change.
Police on 28 May dispersed dozens of protesters who had assembled to denounce the use of force in protests a week before. Protesters were beaten severely and in some cases detained.

On 28 May in Sale, a founder of the February 20 Movement went to the site of the intended rally, but he said that after two minutes, plainclothes police detained him and another demonstrator and put them in a police car.
On May 28 and 29, protesters in Rabat, Casablanca, and Kenitra were beaten severely and in some cases detained.
A pro-reform protester is injured and later dies after police forcibly disperse a group of demonstrators.

Club wielding Moroccan police riding motorcycles drove into crowds of thousands of demonstrators in Casablanca to disperse a protest by pro-democracy activists on 29 May. About an hour after the activists had been dispersed, a few dozen teenage residents of the neighborhood organized their own pro-government demonstration. Around two dozen people were wounded.
On May 28, security forces assaulted protesters in Rabat and Kenitra, and on May 29 in Casablanca and Kenitra.
A protest organised by the pro-reform February 20 movement in the city of Sale on 29 May was violently disrupted.
Police dispersed dozens of people gathered for a protest in the northern city of Tangiers on 29 May.
Anti-government demonstrators gather in two cities to call for political reforms. Police do not engage them.
Anti-government demonstrators gather in two cities to call for political reforms. Police do not engage them.

Hundreds of young Moroccans flouted a government ban and held a peaceful pro-democracy rally in Rabat as authorities promised not to crack down on protesters. The protesters decried the recent beating death of a protester in Safi.
6,000 protesters march throughout Casablanca calling for great democracy and an end to corruption. Police do not engage the demonstrators.

10,000 gather from various groups to protest for government reforms in the Derb Soltaine neighborhood. This protest comes on the heels of a press release by the king claiming institutional reforms, believing these measures do not go far enough. Despite their protests the group made a point that they were still loyal to the king.
Several hundred people gathered in Marrakesh to denounce the kings reform proposals. Police did not intervene to disperse the small, peaceful demonstration.
In Tangiers, several hundred protested in support of bolder reforms and in reject constitutional reforms proposed by King Mohammed VI.

Many gather from various groups to protest for government reforms in the Derb Soltaine neighborhood. This protest comes on the heels of a press release by the king claiming institutional reforms, believing these measures do not go far enough. Despite their protests the group made a point that they were still loyal to the king.
Large numbers gather to protest the aristocracy.

5,000 activists from the February 20 pro-democracy movement marched against the newly proposed constitution in the working-class Hay Mohammedi neighborhood of Casablanca. Simultaneously, pro aristocracy supporters marched at the opposite end of Casablanca. Once police dispersed them, government supporters first blocked then attacked with rocks a march by thousands of activists, wounding many.

On 30 June, young people and teenagers pelted participants in a pro-constitution march with stones and smashed car windscreens in central Laayoune. The police intervened to disperse the demonstrators but no arrested were made or injuries recorded.

On 3 July, authorities in Laayoune blocked a protest march that Saharans wanted to hold on board 4x4 vehicles to protest against the fact that they were banned from setting up tents on the beach in question. Supporters of home Polisario activists and members of the gendarmerie and the paramilitary forces clashed at the Fam-el-Wad beach in Laayoune. Youths carrying Polisario flags and banners with slogans hostile to territorial unity wanted to set up a camp on the beach but the authorities prevented them from doing so for fear of a repetition of what happened in Akdim Izik.

More than 5,000 pro-democracy protesters rallied in Moroccos economic capital Casablanca to denounce a new constitution they say does not go far enough in bringing reforms. Youths threw stones and attacked the democracy activists. In one incident, several activists were trapped in a store and surrounded by government supporters chanting that they were traitors.

1,000 gather to pro-democracy protesters rallied in Moroccos capital to denounce a new constitution. The protesters chanted ""Dignity! Liberty! Social Justice!"" and ""Listen to the voice of the people"".
Several thousand pro-democracy protesters demonstrated in the northern city of Tangier.
Several hundred pro-democracy protesters demonstrated in the central city of Marrakesh.
An AP photographer took pictures of the riots and protests in Casablanca and was set upon by the young men and beaten, his equipment smashed, before police rescued him.

A sit-in was organized on 6 July by several national and international organizations in solidarity with Sahrawi Militant Mustapha Salma Ould Sidi Mouloud. This solidarity act aims to suppprt Ould Sidi Mouloud, who continues to hold a sit-in front of the office of the UNHCR in Nouakchott to draw the international communities attention about his situation after he was separated from his family in Tindouf camps by the polisario militias.
Moroccos Rabat offices of the Unified Socialist Party (who are opposed to the constitution) was attacked by men with sticks.
Moroccan security forces used truncheons, tear gas and water canons on protesters demanding jobs in a remote phosphate mining community which comprises three unincorporated towns.

Thousands of demonstrators, including Islamists, held rallies in Rabat and Casablanca to demand greater political reform and social justice in Morocco. They were met by a handful of counter-demonstrators waving portraits of King Mohammed VI but no incident was reported.
Thousands of demonstrators, including Islamists, held rallies in Rabat and Casablanca to demand greater political reform and social justice in Morocco. 8,000 gather in Casablanca.

Thousands of demonstrators, including Islamists, held peaceful rallies in Rabat, Casablanca and Tangier to demand greater political reforms and social justice in Morocco. Hundreds of pro-government protesters also gathered in Sidi Othmane, waving flags and portraits of King Mohammed VI, chanting: ""Long live the King"" and singing the national anthem.
Thousands of demonstrators, including Islamists, held peaceful rallies in Rabat, Casablanca and Tangier to demand greater political reforms and social justice in Morocco.

Thousands of demonstrators, including Islamists, held peaceful rallies in Rabat, Casablanca and Tangier to demand greater political reforms and social justice in Morocco. A soldier is killed when an armed group crossed the border from Algeria to Ouled Amer hamlet, near Touissit Boubker, in Jerada and engaged them.

""Thousands of Moroccans marched on Sunday to press the Arab worlds longest-ruling dynasty to relinquish more of its sweeping powers and stamp out corruption.The protests coincided with the holding of a centuries-old Beya, or allegiance ceremony, where hundreds of regional representatives renewed vows of obedience to King Mohammed the day after the anniversary of his enthronement.
Thousands march to push King Mohammed to create greater reforms in throughout the county in three cities.

Protesters held a sit-in in Safi on 2 August outside the administration building by the ""Sons of the Deceased and Pensioners of the Phosphate Complex"". Other organizations also came out including Safi graduates of institutions and the unemployed demanding immediate employment and urging the authorities to meet their demands. Security officers and auxiliary forces were brought in from various cities including Kelaat Al Saraghna, Marrakesh, Sidi Bennour and Rabat following incidents during which the police headquarters and an administration building were set on fire.

Security officers and auxiliary forces were brought in from various cities including Kelaat Al Saraghna, Marrakesh, Sidi Bennour and Rabat following incidents during which the police headquarters and an administration building were set on fire. Sporadic protests were staged outside public establishments and some popular districts such as Kors District in Safi, where women and minors staged a protest demanding the release of the detainees and chanting slogans accusing the public forces of setting fire to the aforementioned public establishments.

Thousands gather in several cities to denounce recent political reforms aimed at appeasing them. Moroccans voted overwhelmingly for a package of reforms limiting the kings powers on July 1.

Thousands of protesters turned out in the Sbata neighborhood to demand deep political reform, unappeased by a recently-agreed package limiting the powers of King Mohammed VI. Demonstrators responding to a call from the February 20 Movement filled the cities Al-Harti boulevard, with a crowd police estimated at 5,000 and organizers at 15,000. The group threatened to boycott an upcoming election.

Seven people, including two police were killed in a riot following a soccer match in Moroccos Western Sahara region. One report said the violence flared after Sahrawi activists, who are seeking independence for Western Sahara, became involved.

In the light of the fragile security situation, unknown individuals on 27 September set on fire Irfan school, which is close to Wakalah district, and which is owned by a parliamentarian representing Lagouira, while dozens of the original inhabitants came in droves to the governorate headquarters in protest against the security chaos, and demanded a radical solution for the Wakalah district, and some of them even went further to the extent of demanding the demolishing of this district.
Inhabitants of Laayoune have said that there have been demonstrations witnessed in the city since 27 September in solidarity with Dakhla inhabitants.

The 20 February Movement youths held a two-hour protest march in Hai El Hosseini district of Casablanca on 1 November. The march started directly after the afternoon prayers and was marked by an intense participation of the movements activists coming from various parts of the economic capital (Casablanca). It was confronted by a large presence of the police from various security units.

The 20 February Movement in Casablanca held a protest rally on 1October outside the premises of the Lidik [phonetic] company in Dar El Aman, in El Mohammedi district, to protest against a sharp rise in water and gas bills.

Activists of the 20 February Movement held a hunger strike on 2 October, in solidarity with Safi prisoners. The hunger strike was organized in Independence Square in central town, with the participation of dozens of activists and sympathizers of the movement. Banners and placards were raised signalling the start of the hunger strike. Protests continued the whole day. Locals joined the protest rally where slogans were raised expressing loyalty to detainees accused of subversion and setting fire to public institutions.

February 20 movement held protest marches in Safi and Fes on 2 October calling for for an end to corruption, combating despotism, and offering better basic social services for Moroccans including education, healthcare, jobs and housing. The security forces prevented demonstrators from entering the working class district of Montfleury.

Participants in the 20 February Movement continue their calls for an end to corruption, combating despotism, and offering better basic social services for Moroccans including education, healthcare, jobs and housing in Casablancas El Kassaria Square, in El Mohammedi district. Many participants began a hunger strike.
Police disperse 20 February Movement protesters as soon as they attempt to gather.

Dozens of preachers from mosques across Morocco protested on 10 October in Rabat over tight controls on their preaching, the first time such a demonstration has been allowed to go forward. Police attempted to disperse the protest in front of the parliament, tussling with the imams and briefly detaining three of them.

A member of the February 20 Movement died on 12 October in a protest to demand the right to work when he fell from a roof after being manhandled by police. The man died after being ""pushed by a policeman"" during a sit in above the employment agency (ANAPEC).

Anti-government protesters held a sit-in to demand employment and were ""violently dispersed and confronted"" by police in the Dour lKoucha area of Taza. About 20 people were injured in the resulting clashes and some police vehicles were set on fire.

Clashes pitted the police against mainly unemployed youths and other disadvantaged persons, injuring between 150 and 160 people on both sides. Protests began with youths torching buildings and cars in the city.

For a second day, supporters of the February 20th Movement protested rising utility costs and the recent arrest of activist Bachir Ben Chaib. Confrontations with police led to several arrests.
Authorities arrested prominent February 20th Movement activist, Mohamed Jalloul, while he was leaving work and ""beat him violently"".

On a third day of protests, supporters of the February 20th Movement and security forces clashed causing injuries on both sides. Police used tear gas, clubs, and rocks and made arrests for blocking roads and damaging property.

Clashes continued between supporters of the February 20th Movement and security forces. Protesters blocked roads, burned tires, and held sit-ins and police responded with force and made arrests. Injuries on both sides.

A protest group gathers near a silver mine to attempt to shut off the water supply, believing the company uses too much, leaving the townspeople with less. This protest has been going on sporadically for several months.

Clashes continued between supporters of the February 20th Movement and security forces. Protesters blocked roads, burned tires, and held sit-ins and police responded with force and made at least 6 arrests for ""acts of violence"". Injuries on both sides.

Moroccan police arrested nearly 200 people in clashes before a football match in Casablanca during which shops and public transport were damaged, the interior ministry said on Friday.

Protesters have clashed with government forces in Western Sahara after the U.N. Security Council extended a peacekeeping mission in the disputed territory but without a mandate to monitor human rights.
At least 40 people including eight policemen were injured when a pro-independence demonstration on the disputed Western Sahara turned violent, police and Amnesty International said on Saturday.

Thousands took to the streets of Rabat and Casablanca on Wednesday demanding jobs and higher pay during May Day demonstrations marked by tension, with a large security contingent deployed in the capital. According to Abdel Basset Mahtat, governor of Laayoune, seventy agents from Moroccos security forces were wounded during the events that the city witnessed over the last three days.

Moroccan forces violently dispersed a peaceful protest / demonstration Sunday night organized in the occupied city of Smara, reported a source in the Ministry of Occupied Territories and Communities Abroad.
