column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights
column17: Hundreds of Moroccan rallied outside parliament to protest alleged government interference in the work of independent human rights groups.

column7: Collective of Families of Missing Persons and Detainees in Tindouf Prison
column17: Protesters held a sit-in outside the National Council on Human Rights to draw attention to abuses by Algeria and the Polisario against Moroccans, especially regarding the detention in Tindouf.
Children and children rights associations marched to for children's rights.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights; AI: Amnesty International
column17: At least eight human rights organizations boycotted the World Human Rights Forum in Marrakech.
500 African migrants attempted to storm the barrier to the Spanish enclave of Melilla but were pushed back by Moroccan police.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights; AI: Amnesty International
column17: Human rights organizations gathered near Bab Ejdid to protest the International Human Rights Forum being held in Marrakech.
16 African migrants tried to scale the fence into the Spanish enclave Melilla, and 10 succeeded.

Riot police hit a member of the Moroccan Islamist movement Al Adl wal Ihsan (Justice and Spirituality) while he was demonstrating in Rabat against a draft law prohibiting political gatherings at universities.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights; AI: Amnesty International
column17: Human rights organizations gathered near Bab Ejdid to protest the International Human Rights Forum being held in Marrakech.

column7: FLDF: League of the Democratic Federation of Womens Rights; Women (Morocco)
column17: Women marched for increased rights and to denounce gender-based violence.

column6: Police Forces of Morocco (1999-) Prison Guards
column17: Sahrawi political prisoner Mohamed Babir claims to have been subjected to beatings and torture by prison officers
Saharawi women were dispersed while peacefully protesting for the release of political prisoners, causing injuries.
Saharawi students organized a march in solidarity with the political prisoner Embarak Daoudi who is on hunger strike.
Moroccan police allegedly arrested and tortured a Saharawi man who had participated in human rights demonstrations.

At least 30 were injured, many of them security forces, in clashes between students and police. The students were attempting to block access at the university as part of a strike against exam methods.
A group of saharawi women tried to organized a protest in front of the Court of Appeals in El Aaiun but were violently dispersed by the Moroccan police.
Employees of the Moroccan Pension Fund held a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Finance to protest government action against those who took part in strikes in late October.
More than 100 migrants stormed into the spanish enclave of Melilla while 40 remained on the barrier fence in Morocco before police dispersed them.
Dozens protested in favor of self determination in the Western Sahara and Moroccan security forces responded violently to disperse them, arresting 4.
800 African migrants tried to storm the border fences into the Spanish enclave Melilla. Police repelled most but 54 made it across; at least two police officers were injured.
Moroccan authorities intervened against a sit-in organized by unemployed Saharawis.

The Gendarmerie forces arbitrarily arrested Trade union leader, Najim Adjaer during his trade union activities and the struggle along with workers at educational institution, where he was protesting in Ras el-Ma'a against behavior of its director. Najim Adjaer had earlier received insults and verbal abuse by director of the educational institution in latter's endeavor to finish off free and democratic trade union action that call for respecting rights of workers.

column16: Maghreb Arabe Presse; La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco)
column17: Hundreds held a sit-in to show solidarity with French victims of the Charlie Hebdo attacks.
About 300 African migrants tried to cross a border fence from the Moroccan side trying to enter the Spanish territory of Melilla. 14 crossed into Spain and the rest were diverted by security forces.
Hundreds held a sit-in to show solidarity with French victims of the Charlie Hebdo attacks.
Journalists held a sit-in in condemnation of the Charlie Hebdo attacks in France.
A sit-in was held in solidarity with French victims of the Charlie Hebdo attacks.
A sit-in was held in solidarity with French victims of the Charlie Hebdo attacks.
Moroccan police used force to stop a peaceful demonstration by Saharawis.
Fans at a Raja Casablanca football game chanted anti-Charlie Hebdo slogans in a match attended by 40,000 people.
Young Saharawis held a sit-in to protest policies of marginalization and deprivation.
Saharawi women held a sit-in against Moroccan occupation and installed a tent outside the city to continue their protest. Moroccan forces stopped the protest.
Moroccan forces dispersed a sit-in organized by young Saharawis arguing for employment.
One hundred salafist men demonstrated after Friday prayer to protest the French publication Charlie Hebdos caricatures of the prophet Mohammed.

Moroccan security forces ""blocked"" a banned protest by Saharawi women who tried to demonstrate in favor of political prisoners. Some reports indicate the authorities also injured demonstrators attempting to hold a peaceful sit-in but this is unconfirmed.
A young Saharawi man was attacked by an unknown group of Moroccans and later died from his injuries.
Saharawi protesters were dispersed by Moroccan authorities.

At 2am, around 400 African migrants attempted to storm Melillas fences and were repulsed by Spanish authorities. Hours later, another 200 charged the fence and were repulsed by Spanish authorities. 5 were injured and 35 made it across to Spain.

Moroccan security forces raided a makeshift mountain camp and rounded up 1,200 migrants, injuring several, burning tents and destroying belongings. The migrants were arrested and/or bused to remote towns in the south of Morocco, and around 200 hundred escaped.

Tens of Saharawi protesters demonstrated against the presence of Moroccan forces, the detainment of Saharawi political prisoners, and the recent death of a young Saharawi man. Moroccan forces used batons and stones to disperse the protesters, injuring several.
Hundreds of Saharawi protesters marched in favor of Western Sahara self determination. Moroccan security forces ""repressed"" the event.
Saharawi demonstrators were violently dispersed by Moroccan security forces while participating in a sit-in in Semara. At least two demonstrators required hospital care.
Around 150 people held a demonstration to commemorate the 4th anniversary of the February 20th movement that started in reaction to the Arab Spring.
Around 200 people held a demonstration to commemorate the 4th anniversary of the February 20th movement that started in reaction to the Arab Spring.

Tens of Sahrawis protested to demand the departure of Moroccan occupation and the right of the Sahrawi people to self-determination. Moroccan forces attacked the participants with stones and ""ransacked the homes of Sahrawi citizens in Smara.""
Unemployed Saharawi graduates held a demonstration against Moroccan occupation and exclusion of Saharawi people.
Saharawi women protested against foreign companies and Moroccan forces in the Western Sahara territory.

column16: Morocco World News; La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco); AFP
column17: At least ten thousand protested in favor of gender parity and women's rights.
Moroccan security forces have reportedly attacked a group of Sahrawi activists coordinating an event to supporting working Sahrawi women.
Several vigils were staged by Sahrawi demonstrators to protest the involvement of foreign companies in resource extraction.
Moroccan security forces reportedly violently dispersed a demonstration for Sahrawi self-determination.
About 400 Moroccans and Tunisian expats held a peaceful protest to condemn the militant attack of the Bardo Museum in Tunis.
Dozens of sub-Saharan refugees held a sit-in to protest poor living conditions.

Thousands of Islamists held a sit-in against hundreds of riot police when they were prevented from burying the widow of their spiritual leader. After several hours, police allowed supporters into the cemetery.
Security forces reportedly used force to disperse a peaceful demonstration for Saharawi self determination.

column7: CODESA: Collective of Saharawi Human Rights Defenders
column16: Morocco World News; Front Line Defenders; Sahara Press Service
column17: Reports of the forceful repression of a demonstration calling for an independent UN human rights monitoring system in Western Sahara, which was being held on the street outside the house of human rights defender and CODESA president, Aminatou Haidar. The police reportedly subsequently attacked and damaged Haidars home. Other witnesses dispute that the damage was caused by the police, and maintain that pro-Polisario forces attacked the house.
Saharawi human rights activist attacked by policemen after participating in a peaceful political demonstration calling for self-determination in the Western Sahara.
Employees laid off from Kreef Company, located in Tangier Free Industrial Zone, were attacked by the company's security guards while they were gathering outside.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers
column17: Labor unions marched against ""antisocial"" government policies.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers
column17: Labor unions marched against ""antisocial"" government policies.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers
column17: Labor unions marched against ""antisocial"" government policies.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers
column17: Labor unions marched against ""antisocial"" government policies.
Saharawi activists marched in protest of Moroccan occupation of the Western Sahara. They were dispersed by Moroccan security forces.
Angry passengers stand on the train tracks at the Temara station in protest of repeated delays.
Moroccan forces ""intervened violently"" against Saharawi activities who were holding a sit-in near the city of Semara.

column16: La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco); Morocco World News
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a march was held in Beni Mellal.

column16: Morocco World News; La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco)
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a rally was held in Fez.

column16: La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco); Morocco World News
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a rally was held in Guelmim.

column16: La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco); Morocco World News
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a march and a rally were held in Marrakesh.

column16: La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco); Morocco World News
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a rally was held in Oujda.

column16: La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco); Morocco World News
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a rally was held in Semara.

column16: Morocco World News; La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco)
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a rally was held in Tan Tan

column16: Morocco World News; La Nouvelle Tribune (Morocco)
column17: Despite a boycott of labor day festivities by four major unions, a rally was held in Tangier.
Moroccan forces ""attacked"" Saharawi activists staging a protest in recognition of International Labor Day. Several were reported injured.
The Democratic Union of Justice (SDJ) led a sit-in in front of the trial court in Essaouira to protest the recent firing of the chief clerk.
The Democratic Union of Justice (SDJ) led a sit-in in front of the trial court in Essaouira to protest the recent firing of the chief clerk.
Moroccan authorities ""repressed"" Saharawi activities who were conducting a sit-in to demand employment, leaving several injured.

8 security forces and 20 students were injured and 6 were arrested in clashes during protests in front of a court in Fez. The protesters brought knives and sticks and threw stones to protest the trial of a political activist charged with murder.

An angry mob attacked a presumed homosexual young man but were stopped by a policeman. One month later, a video of the incident was made public and police arrested two men suspected of participating in the attack.
Two French members of the activist group Femen protested topless in front of the Hassan Tower in Rabat and were arrested by police. They were later expelled from the country.

Two Moroccan men were arrested after they kissed in front of the Hassan Tower in Rabat to protest anti-gay laws and in solidarity with recently arrested Femen activists. They were later sentenced to four months in jail.

After two gay men were arrested for kissing in protest at the Hassan Tower in Rabat, TV channel Al Aoula aired their pictures and full names, prompting tens of protesters to gather outside one of their homes and threaten his family.
Outside the French embassy in Rabat, thousands protested the recent activities of French activists from the Femen group in Morocco.
A Saharawi man was assaulted by Moroccan forces after participating in a peaceful demonstration to support a Saharawi woman in the Canary Islands who is on a hunger strike.

An angry crowd surrounded two women wearing ""indecent"" dresses in a market near Agadir; at least two men verbally and physically assaulted them before police intervened and arrested the women. Police later also arrested the two men accused of assault and harassment.

column7: YFDC: Youth Forum for Democracy and Citizenship
column17: Members of the Youth Forum for Democracy and Citizenship organized a peaceful march against racism and xenophobia, commemorating World Refugee Day by marching through Rabat offering symbolic flowers to immigrants.
At the Hassan Tower in Rabat, the Masayminch group of activists protested laws against public eating during Ramadan.

A mob took to the streets to protest a Senegalese immigrant who refused to vacate his rented apartment after a dispute with his landlord. The protesters demanded that the authorities remove the Senegalese man and expel other sub-Saharan migrants.
Around 300 held a sit-in to protest the recent arrest of two women for wearing dresses that were deemed inappropriate.
Around 500 protested against the recent arrest of two women for wearing dresses that were deemed inappropriate.
Saharawi protesters held a peaceful sit-in against unemployment, marginalisation, and ""systematic exclusion"" by the Moroccan government.

Police ordered sub-Saharan migrants to vacate buildings in the Boukhalef neighborhood of Tangier where they were squatting, and then raided several of those buildings. At the same time, clashes erupted between locals and the migrants that left one migrant dead after he was wounded with ""a sharp object"".

Hundreds of people affiliated with the PJD tried to remain in mosques after prayer time without a permit and police intervened to forcibly remove them in Oujda, Berkane, Jerada, Eastern Laayone, Taourirt, and Ain Beni Metahhar.

Hundreds of people affiliated with the PJD tried to remain in mosques after prayer time without a permit and police intervened to forcibly remove them in Oujda, Berkane, Jerada, Eastern Laayone, Taourirt, and Ain Beni Metahhar.

Hundreds of people affiliated with the PJD tried to remain in mosques after prayer time without a permit and police intervened to forcibly remove them in Oujda, Berkane, Jerada, Eastern Laayone, Taourirt, and Ain Beni Metahhar.

Hundreds of people affiliated with the PJD tried to remain in mosques after prayer time without a permit and police intervened to forcibly remove them in Oujda, Berkane, Jerada, Eastern Laayone, Taourirt, and Ain Beni Metahhar.

Hundreds of people affiliated with the PJD tried to remain in mosques after prayer time without a permit and police intervened to forcibly remove them in Oujda, Berkane, Jerada, Eastern Laayone, Taourirt, and Ain Beni Metahhar.

Hundreds of people affiliated with the PJD tried to remain in mosques after prayer time without a permit and police intervened to forcibly remove them in Oujda, Berkane, Jerada, Eastern Laayone, Taourirt, and Ain Beni Metahhar.
Moroccan security forces forcifully dispersed a sit-in organized by the Local Coordination of Unemployed Saharawi Graduates, injuring at least one protester.

column6: Government of Libya (2014-) House of Representatives
column8: UNSMIL: United Nations Support Mission in Libya (2011-)
column17: Agreement: In Skhirat, Libyan parties including the Tobruk-based parliament, representatives of political parties, municipalities and civil society organizations initialised a UN-brokered political agreement despite the absence of the General National Congress (GNC).
After 2 men were accused of theft, a mob beat and threw stones at them, killing 1 and injuring the other.

Around 100 Moroccan journalists and activists demonstrated in front of the Moroccan parliament in solidarity with an editor who has been on a month-long hunger strike over his treatment by the government.
A small land mine detonated in the Lemsaid region near Tan Tan, injuring a Saharawi boy.
Police tortured a Saharawi activist, Leila Leili, at the Casablanca airport where she was returning from a Polisario event in Algeria.
Moroccan security forces reportedly ""repressed"" a protest by Saharawi activists and attacked the homes of Saharawi people in the Oum Tounsi neighborhood of Dakhla.
Protesters shouted at Prime Minister Benkirane while he was giving a political speech in favor of PJD candidates. Some were able to break through security and attempt to attack Benkirane.
Prisoners at a juvenile detention center set the facility on fire, killing one and injuring others.

column9: USFP: The Socialist Union of Popular Forces
column17: Supporters of former minister of Youth and Sports Mohamed Ouzzine attacked at least 3 USFP candidates while Ouzzine was campaigning for upcoming elections. The victims were taken to the hospital for medical care.
Voting was stalled after 8 people stormed the voting station and ransacked the ballot box. Two of the culprits were later arrested.
Four PJD supporters attacked a member of the PAM who was filming them trying to mobilize voters.
In the Boussakoura neighborhood of Casablanca, opposing political gropus blocked streets and exchanged threats on election day. Local authorities intervened to free access to the street.
Saharawi students held a ""peaceful demonstration"" to condemn recent elections. The protest was ""violently dispersed"" by Moroccan forces.
Two Saharawi civilians were ""victims of a brutal aggression by Moroccan forces"" which required medical attention.

After the National Education Ministry announced the names of candidates who passed the written exam for the Regional Centers for Education and Training, serious fraud claims led to protests in front of the center in Rabat and ""in most Moroccan cities.""

After the National Education Ministry announced the names of candidates who passed the written exam for the Regional Centers for Education and Training, serious fraud claims led to protests in front of the center in Rabat and ""in most Moroccan cities.""

After the National Education Ministry announced the names of candidates who passed the written exam for the Regional Centers for Education and Training, serious fraud claims led to protests in front of the center in Rabat and ""in most Moroccan cities.""
Saharawi activities held ""massive demonstrations"" calling for self-determination. Moroccan forces ""brutally dispersed them"", leaving one injured.

column6: Police Forces of Morocco (1999-) Prison Guards
column17: Political prisoners from the Saharawi group Gdeim Izik were reportedly ""tortured"", leaving three wounded.

Saharawi demonstrators held a protest which was dispersed by police who arrested 9; 6 were later convicted of ""inciting violence against the forces of security"". Pro-Saharawi sources say the demonstration was peaceful and police ""brutally repressed"" them, while government sources say the protesters attacked security forces with rocks, sticks, and flaming bottles. Several police and protesters may have been injured.
Hundreds of African migrants charged at the border with the Spanish territory of Ceuta. 87 made it across and 13 others were hurt. Moroccan forces held back many of the migrants.
Tens of thousands protested outside the Swedish embassy, demanding Sweden drop its plans to recognize an independent republic in the Western Sahara.
About 130 migrants tried to cross into the Spanish territory of Melilla. Most were arrested, 50 stormed the fence, and 30 succeeded in crossing. 2 were treated for injuries.
Anti-death penalty activists protested in front of Parliament.
Mothers of 7 political prisoners held a peaceful sit-in to demand the release of their children.
Moroccan forces ""brutally repressed"" a demonstration by Saharawi activists, leaving several injured.
Unemployed nurses marched to protest government employment policies.
Thousands marched in support of Palestine.
Thousands of medical students marched to protest mandatory civil service.
Dozens of youth held a sit-in in front of the National Council for Human Rights in memory of the ""martyr"" Mehdi Ben Barka.
Thousands marched to protest high utility prices.
Saharawi youth held a protest against the Kings visit to the Western Sahara.
Authorities ""brutually repressed"" a protest against the kings visit to the Western Sahara, causing two injuries.
Hundreds of protesters continued to demonstrate against the Amendis utilities company.
Thousands, including Saharawi leaders, held a sit-in in front of MINURSO to demonstrate support for the King and for autonomy for the Western Sahara under Moroccan rule.
Doctors held a sit-in on the Ain Diab boardwalk as part of ongoing national protests against the Ministry of Health, demanding improved working conditions.
Doctors and residents held a sit-in outside of Ibn Rochd hospital as part of ongoing national protests against the Ministry of Health, demanding improved working conditions and training policies.
Political party representatives, activists, journalists, and other members of civil society held a sit-in in solidarity with the families of victims of terror attacks in Paris.
Close to 100 migrants tried to storm the border fence into Melilla, but police stopped most. 30 climbed the fence, but only two made it over and one was seriously injured when he fell.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers
column17: Unions organized a protest where over 10,000 marched against government policies and high cost of living.
Moroccan forces ""violently dispersed a peaceful demonstration"" of Saharawis protesting unemployment rates. Several injured.
Train passengers angry about delays jumped onto the tracks and blocked trains from leaving the Kenitra station.
Train passengers angry about delays jumped onto the tracks and blocked trains from leaving the Agdal station in Rabat.
Student teachers at the Regional Center for Education and Training of Khouribga held a sit-in against the local office of the Ministry of Education.
Around 600 taxi drivers protested outside the Moroccan Labor Union headquarters to denounce the Uber company.
Thousands of teacher trainees protested government recruitment and funding policies.

column6: Government of Libya (2014-) House of Representatives
column7: UNSMIL: United Nations Support Mission in Libya (2011-)
column8: Government of Libya (2014-) General National Congress
column17: Agreement: Lawmakers from Libyas rival parliaments signed an UN-brokered deal to form a unity government.
Three migrants drowned and about 20 were hospitalized when hundreds tried to cross into Ceuta. Some injuries may have been caused by security forces as 250 were arrested.
Teacher trainees held sit-ins as part of a national movement against reduced stipends and other employment practices.
Teacher trainees held sit-ins as part of a national movement against reduced stipends and other employment practices.
Between 800 and 2,000 teacher trainees marched in Casablanca to protest several policies and police used ""excessive force"" to disperse them. Around 40 were injured.
Teacher trainees were beaten by police while protesting. Around 100 were injured in Inezgane, where the level of violence was especially high.
Teacher trainees held sit-ins and were met with ""extreme violence"" from the police. Around 20 were injured.
Teacher trainees were beaten by police while protesting. Around 8 were injured.
Teacher trainees were beaten by police while protesting. A total of over 280 protesters were injured throughout the nation.
Protesters from a wide range of groups marched in general opposition to the political system.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers
column17: Nearly 2,000 protesters led by four main unions held a sit-in in front of Parliament and threatened a general strike to protest various policies including pension reform.
After police beat protesters on Jan 7th, teacher trainees continue to protest regularly in Inezgane. No further violence reported.
Amazigh activists protested in front of PJD headquarters in response to an ""anti-Amazigh"" statement by the Prime Minister.

""Scores"" of protesters and supporters of the Feb 20 Movement protested in front of parliament, denouncing ministers retirement benefits. Pro-government protesters attempted to rush the Feb 20 Movement protesters, but police prevented them from clashing.
Authorities intervened violently to disperse a demonstration by Saharawi activists, causing several injuries.
Thousands marched along with teacher trainees in opposition to decrees by the Ministry of Education.
Anti-Polisario protesters marched and burned Polisario flags while chanting anti-Algeria slogans after claims that Polisario attacked Amazigh people on Moroccan university campuses.

Sahrawi human rights activist Alisalem Tamek started Saturday an open-ended sit-in in the Principal Square in Assa, South of Morocco, to protest against being systematically banned from the right to continue his higher studies since 2007 in the Moroccan universities.
Hundreds marched to celebrate the anniversary of the founding of the February 20 Movement.

column16: Agence Nouakchott d'Information; Sahara Press Service
column17: The Moroccan army killed a Saharawi businessman in the territories controlled by Polisario. The accident occurred Saturday in the area called Djbailat Albid, located in the region of Guelt, in the buffer zone where the use of weapons is forbidden under the cease-fire signed between the two parties of the conflict in Western Sahara, the Polisario Front and Morocco.
Students staged a protest during a public speech delivered by PM Benkirane in Oujda. They showed the photos of the teachers victim of police violence earlier this year.
Workers protest turned violent in Essaouira on Wednesday.

Up to 1 million marched to protest recent remarks by UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moons critical remarks about Moroccan control over the Western Sahara. Government sources cite over 3 million protesters.

Tetouan instant court sentenced four university students to one year and another four to six-month imprisonment in the aftermath of a protest at their university. The protests took place on March 15, 2016 where the security forces broke into the university to disburse the students' protest.

Tetouan instant court sentenced four university students to one year and another four to six-month imprisonment in the aftermath of a protest at their university. The protests took place on March 15, 2016 where the security forces broke into the university to disburse the students' protest.

Pro-government protesters ""laid siege"" outside of MINURSO offices in the Western Sahara (Assa, Zag, Mahbes, Litzouizgui, Birat, Laouina-Lahna, and Laouina-Igman) to express their outrage at recent remarks by UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon regarding Moroccan ""occupation"" of the territory.

Pro-government protesters ""laid siege"" outside of MINURSO offices in the Western Sahara (Assa, Zag, Mahbes, Litzouizgui, Birat, Laouina-Lahna, and Laouina-Igman) to express their outrage at recent remarks by UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon regarding Moroccan ""occupation"" of the territory.

Pro-government protesters ""laid siege"" outside of MINURSO offices in the Western Sahara (Assa, Zag, Mahbes, Litzouizgui, Birat, Laouina-Lahna, and Laouina-Igman) to express their outrage at recent remarks by UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon regarding Moroccan ""occupation"" of the territory.

Pro-government protesters ""laid siege"" outside of MINURSO offices in the Western Sahara (Assa, Zag, Mahbes, Litzouizgui, Birat, Laouina-Lahna, and Laouina-Igman) to express their outrage at recent remarks by UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon regarding Moroccan ""occupation"" of the territory.
Angry protesters halted construction of a pool as it dug up an old cemetery.
Protesters demonstrated in front of Parliament to decry the execution of stray dogs in Kser El Kbir.
Hundreds of unemployed people marched to demand government jobs. Police intervened to disperse them.

Outside a trial for men accused of beating homosexual, around 100 anti-homosexual protesters gathered. Two gay rights activists from France tried to pose topless in a counter-protest, but were arrested and deported.
Street vendors demonstrated to demand an investigation into the death of a woman who set herself on fire to protest against the seizure of her goods by local authorities.
Protesters marched to mark Labor Day, demanding increased benefits for workers.

Under more than 400 meters underground a group of 2 miners continued their strike that started on Monday to demand better social conditions. Dozens of workers protested at the ""Ighram Oosar"" and ""Ait Sidi Ahmed Oouhmd"" mines near the city of M'Rirt. The General Union of Moroccan Workers sent a letter to the Minister of Energy and Minerals, Abdelkader Aamara, calling him to ""intervene urgently to save the lives of the protesters and resolve their issues."" In the letter addressed to the minister on Tuesday, May 3, 2016 the union said that ""more than 120 workers staged a sit-in underground tunnels 650 meters in depth in very dangerous circumstances due to heat and lack of ventilation and security to demand better work conditions having exhausted negotiations.

column16: Sahara Press Service; Algeria Press Service
column17: A teenager aged 12 passed away following injuries caused by the explosion of an anti-truck mine in Gsaibat Lmairig (occupied town of Mehbes).
Anti-government group at university accused a young woman of ""spying for the Moroccan police."" They publicly beat and kicked her, shaved her eyebrows and cut her hair publicly.

About 100 students protested to demand payment of scholarships, throwing stones at security forces who used water canons and pushed them back. 25 students and 10 security injured, 4 students arrested.
Mob beat a man for breaking Ramadan fast in public by smoking.

column9: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights
column17: Human rights activist and her husband assaulted by crowd for wearing ""inappropriate dress"" during Ramadan.
Tens of Moroccan women from civil society organizations protested in front of Parliament, demanding equality and legal reform for women.
A mob beat a diabetic person seen drinking water during daylight hours in the month of Ramadan.
Scores of people gathered outside the Parliament Building in Rabat on Sunday to protest the proposed pension system reforms.
Arrests: Throughout the country, police arrested 143 and detained 52 suspected of planning to set up a branch of the Islamic State and carry out attacks.
Sit-in in front of Parliament to protest pension reforms. Authorities broke up the protest by verbally informing them it was banned.
Doctors marched to protest new health insurance laws.
Thousands marched in protest of a new law that would move the retirement age from 60 to 63.

column9: Police Forces of Morocco (1999-) Prison Guards
column17: Inmates at juvenile detention center tried to escape, setting fire to beds and a bus and lightly wounding staff. Police stopped them, resulting in nine injuries.
A few dozen February 20th Movement protesters demonstrated in front of Parliament, decrying government corruption.

The employees of Atento Morocco arranged a sit-in outside the headquarters of the company in Casablanca, to protest against the administration for avoiding legal obligations towards them. The Moroccan Labour Union said that the strike came after they have exhausted all efforts to make the company's management respond to their demands.
Police ""used violence"" to disperse protesters demanding jobs in education. Two seriously injured.

Moroccan forces forcefully repressed a peaceful demonstration organized by young Sahrawis at the Foum Al Ouad beach, located 25km west of the city of occupied Al Ayun. Sahrawi protestors chanted slogans claiming Sahrawi peoples right to self-determination and independence, denouncing the systematic plundering of Western Saharas natural resources. The Moroccan security forces, in uniform and in plainclothes, used force to break up the demonstration, leaving many injured among the protestors.

Movement of forces: Armed Polisario Front fighters were reportedly confronting Moroccan security forces in Guarguarat, in the buffer zone between Morocco and Mauritania. The Polisario Front has moved troops within 200 meters of Moroccan police raising concerns of imminent armed conflict. The new development on the ground has prompted the United Nations Secretary General to issue a statement on Sunday in which he expressed his concern at the escalation of tension in the region.

Hundreds of people marched on Sunday in the Moroccan city of Casablanca against the Islamist ruling party of Justice and Development Party (PJD). The march was initiated by some civil society groups on social media ahead of the upcoming parliamentary elections on Oct. 7.

A Sahrawi citizen passed away following the explosion of an anti-tank mine while was aboard his car in Skikima. A similar episode occurred in May, when a teenager aged 12 passed away following injuries caused by the explosion of an anti-truck mine in Gsaibat Lmairig (occupied town of Mehbes).

According to the Ministry of Interior, two police officers were injured as they tried to disperse two sit-ins of PJD sympathizers in Kenitra and Berkane. The party denied being involved in the violent episodes.

According to the Ministry of Interior, two police officers were injured as they tried to disperse two sit-ins of PJD sympathizers in Kenitra and Berkane. The party denied being involved in the violent episodes.

PJD members organized a sit-in near the prefecture to protest against alleged ""frauds"" during vote counting. The sit-in was organized Saturday after the governor rejected their request to recount the votes and correct ""the mistake."" The next day, Tazi and his runner-up, Hicham Lemsaadi, met with the PJDs lawyers and announced their decision to resort to court.

Representatives of different political parties protested in the northern Moroccan city of Huceima against ""frauds"" in the October 7 elections. Protestors went out into the streets of Huceima to denounce what they consider fraud in favor of one party.

Demonstrators in the Agadir region of southern Morocco clashed with police on Wednesday over the demolition of homes built without permits, causing injuries and material damage. Security forces were backed up by a dozen police cars and almost 500 people took part in the protest,during which cars were set ablaze and banks and shops damaged, while a local administration office was also torched. The demonstrators cut off the main road through Sidi Bibi and encircled the police station.
Moroccan police repressed a protest march in Casablanca. Between 25 and 30 demonstrators were injured.
Protests against the pension reform took place in Casablanca, Tetouan, Agadir and Fes. The biggest demonstration rallied 2000 thousand people in Fes.

Moroccos forces violently repressed a peaceful protest, staged in Smara, in the Sahrawi city of Al-Ayun. The protesters chanted slogans calling for a referendum on the self-determination of Sahrawi people and the return of the civilian staff of the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara (MINURSO). The Moroccan forces besieged all streets leading to the district of Smara before violently intervening against the Sahrawi protesters, leaving many of them injured.
Police clashes with farmers in Settat. Several were injured.

The city of Al-Hoceima is in turmoil following the death of a fish-seller who threw himself in a garbage truck. The incident occurred after the deceased was protesting against the authorities decision to confiscate his merchandise. Yesterday, Al-Hoceimas population took to the street, staging a peaceful sit-in in order to stand in solidarity with the deceased, who was earning his living from fish-selling. The protesters demanded the urgent presence of Al-Hoceimas Governor to the area in order to discuss the incident and open an investigation to find out the exact details behind the fish-sellers death.

Thousands of protesters in northern Morocco on Friday demanded justice for a fish seller whose death when he was crushed in a rubbish truck sparked nationwide outrage. Protests were held in Al Hoceima and Nador.

On Saturday, Hoceima residents held a candlelight vigil for Mouhcine Fikri before holding a gathering on the towns central square in their latest show of anger over the fish sellers death.

Nearly 2,000 people have marched to the Moroccan Parliament to protest the death of a fish vendor and to express a broader anger over alleged corruption by police and government officials.Protesters in the Moroccan capital chanted ""We are all Mouhcine"" on Sunday as they marched down the main avenue toward Parliament. They also held banners reading ""No to Corruption"" and ""No to Humiliation.""

The Moroccan forces suppressed a peaceful demonstration organized by the Sahrawi people in the city of El-Ayun to claim their rights to a decent life and denounces the illegal exploitation by Morocco of the Sahrawi natural resources.

Moroccans burn an Israeli flag during a protest rally in the capital, Rabat, on November 9, 2016. Hundreds of people in Morocco have held a protest rally in the capital to vent their anger at the Israeli flag being flown at UN climate talks in the central city of Marrakesh.

column17: 10 November. A Saharawi activist has been jailed and tortured by the Moroccan security forces in Guelmim.

Thousands protested in north Morocco on Friday to demand justice for a fishmonger whose death when he was crushed in a garbage truck sparked outrage nationwide. ""Rest, Mouhcine. We will continue the fight!"" crowds chanted on Friday, according to footage streamed live on social media. Protesters including many young people marched through the northern cities streets, carrying candles and flowers, and waving Berber flags.

Several thousand activists have marched in the Moroccan city of Marrakech to demand environmental justice, just a few kilometers (miles) away from where high-level U.N. climate change talks are being held. Native Americans protesting against the Dakota Access Pipeline demonstrated Sunday alongside local indigenous Amazigh groups protesting against a Moroccan companies expropriation of water resources, in addition to dozens of international civil society groups.

column17: CNES protested against the failed respect of the agreements signed by the government.

Hundreds of people protested on Saturday, demanding justice for a fishmonger whose death sparked outrage nationwide, while calling for ""dignity"".""Freedom, justice"" and ""Long live the people!"" cried demonstrators in the northern city of Al-Hoceima, where Mouhcine Fikri, 31, died last month.

New protests were reported from Al Hoceima, northern Morocco, 40 days after the death of a fisherman in the same town. Thousands of protesters coming from all parts of the region took to the streets marching peacefully and chanting slogans.
Hundreds of people staged protest marches in several Moroccan cities against a proposed education reform. The biggest demonstration was staged in Casablanca.
Hundreds of people staged protest marches in several Moroccan cities against a proposed education reform. The biggest demonstration was staged in Casablanca.
A young Saharawi woman was arrested during a protest sit-in in the occupied Saharan territories, according to a Saharan association based in Spain. She was also injured during her arrest.
Armed men attacked protesters in Nador with knives. Several were injured and hospitalised.

column7: UNEM: National Union of Moroccan Students; PSU: Unified Socialist Party; PADS: Democratic and Socialist Vanguard Party; USFP: The Socialist Union of Popular Forces
column17: The expropriation of the UNEM offices in Rabat by the state triggered protests in the capital. Thousands of people marched peacefully in the city centre.

Moroccan military forces have violently repressed a peaceful Saharawi protest in al-Ayun, who were claiming Western Sahara people's right to self-determination and independence. The Saharawi protestors chanted slogans calling for an end to Moroccan occupation and respect of human rights in the occupied territories of Western Sahara. They also demanded that all political Saharawi prisoners in Moroccan jails be set free.

Police have dispersed a protest in Morocco's northern city of Al-Hoceima, months after a local fishmonger's death in a garbage truck sparked unrest. Security forces broke up the protest in the city centre late Wednesday as the demonstrators did not have a permit to protest. The security authorities had mobilised a large number of their members and besieged the square from all sides, and reinforced their presence with a water cannon vehicle before intervening, using batons and sticks to beat up protesters who went on chanting slogans stressing the peaceful nature of their protests.

The Moroccan military forces violently crushed, Wednesday in Al-Ayun, a peaceful protest of the Sahrawi Coordination of Unemployed Graduates against the plundering of the natural resources of Western Sahara. The protesters chanted slogans denouncing Morocco's illegal exploitation of Sahrawi people's resources in blatant violation of the international law and conventions.

A group of inhabitants from Douar Amiadi in Chefchaouene clashed with police during a drug enforcement operation. The residents uses stones and batons to resist the police intervention, while the gendarmes shot fires in the air to disperse the crowd.

A student demonstration was reported in Casablanca on 25 January. Initial reports claimed that students set the school on fire and clashed with police but these claims were rejected by the French Embassy.

column7: CNES: National Coordination of Trainee Teachers; UMT: Moroccan Labour Union
column17: Thousands of Moroccans took to the streets of Rabat on Sunday for anti-government demonstrations calling for action against corruption and better conditions for trainee teachers. More than 1,000 labour union members, supporters of leftist parties and activists joined a first march in the capital

New protests erupted in Al Hoceima and Boukidan (Sidi Bouafif) on Sunday. According to local media, clashes between protesters and the police in Boukidan lasted for nearly 7 hours straight. Young people poured in from neighbouring towns and villages, particularly from Imzourene, to lend support to the protesters. Power outages were detected and several roads in the area were blocked. Around 30 police officers were wounded.

New protests erupted in Al Hoceima and Boukidan (Sidi Bouafif) on Sunday. According to local media, clashes between protesters and the police in Boukidan lasted for nearly 7 hours straight. Young people poured in from neighbouring towns and villages, particularly from Imzourene, to lend support to the protesters. Power outages were detected and several roads in the area were blocked. Around 30 police officers were wounded.

Morocco- the Fatiha village workers in the province of Sidi Slimane protest against the banning of some workers from their jobs. The company recently stopped a group of seven workers immediately after joining the Syndicate of the Moroccan Labor Union and the establishment of a trade union office, as they prepared a logistical dossier project stipulated in the Labor Code, but rather the administrator of the company proceeded to ban them from work instead of responding to their legitimate rights.
Dozens of nurses protested in front of the Office of the Social Security, on Thursday morning in Casablanca, demanding their right of health insurance and to demand their 2 months delayed salaries.

the company ""Averda"" workers staged a protest in front of the company's headquarters to protest the lack of response to their fair and legitimate demands, and the failure to provide the necessary and appropriate work conditions

column17: Trade unions marched in protest in the Moroccan capital Rabat.
People demonstrated in Al Hoceima to demand the liberation of prisoners.

A trainee teacher suffered a miscarriage after security forces assaulted dozens of teachers who protested demanding records of examinations in front of the headquarters of the National Center for exams.
Demonstrating teachers were violent repressed by police in Rabat. Several sustained serious injuries.
A group of unemployed people protested on a bus threatening suicide in southern Morocco.

A group of protesters emerged last Saturday [25 Mar] and asked Saadeddine El Othmani, the new head of government-designate, to give jobs in the civil service to hundreds of cadres, as promised by his predecessor. The protesters warned of more protests ahead against the new government if it does not listen to the voice of the street. They came from many towns and staged a march from the Essouissi university campus to the Bab El Ahad square that has been the scene of thousands of protests in the past.

Fourteen people were arrested following the rally that was organized on Sunday in the centres of Imzouren and Beni Bouayach (El Hoceima Province). The demonstrations, motivated by economic demands, saw police buildings torched and police vehicles destroyed.

A peaceful demonstration took place in Al Hoceima on 29 march, one after the dismissal of the local governor.

column17: The National University of Health, affiliated with the Moroccan Union of Labor, condemned the harassment of the nurses who were marching in front of the Ministry of Health on Thursday morning in Rabat, which coincides with the first day of the new government.
Hundreds of demonstrators held a march on Sunday in Casablanca to support the Palestinian people and protest against Israel.
The day before an official visit of Morocco's new Interior minister, thousands of protesters marched in the northern town of Al Hoceima, displaying banners with images of local heroes.

Violent clashes broke out in the Moroccan city of Fes on Thursday as security forces fired tear gas at radical leftist students. Activists and news reports said some 45 people from both sides had been injured in the confrontation on the edge of the central city's university campus and outside the main court. The protesters had come to offer support to two leftist students appearing in court, charged with the murder of an Islamist student who died of his injuries after clashes between the two camps in April 2014.
A massive demonstration took place in Midar on Wednesday to demand social and economic rights.
Movement of forces: Polisario Front retreated its forces from the Guerguerat buffer zone.

Workers led by labour trade unions marched on May day in Rabat, calling for improved labour right. Migrant workers also joined the protest, denouncing injustice by Moroccans employers. Protesters in Rabat burnt flags of the Israeli regime on May Day as a show of support for a group of Palestinian prisoners who have remained on hunger strike in Israeli prisons for more than two weeks.

Over 1,800 Moroccans, largely from the border town of Fnideq, gathered at the crossing point with Ceuta's border to protest mistreatment by border authorities, particularly of female porters. Moroccan authorities closed the border to assess the situation.
Unknown gunmen killed a photojournalist for the state-run Maghreb Arabe Presse at his home in Temara. Police later arrested five suspects.

Human rights associations and activists staged a sit-in in front of the Palestinian Embassy in Rabat in solidarity with the ongoing hunger strike of imprisoned Palestinians in Israel, with some entering a hunger strike of their own. A similar solidarity action had taken place on May Day.
Workers of a tourist hotel in Marrakech staged a series of strikes and sit-ins in front the establishment to denounce laying off practices as the hotel is due to shut down.
Protest organized by workers of 'Amanor company "" in Tetouan industrial area. One worker attempted to suicide himself during the protest.
Thousands of people banged on saucepans and marched in Al Hoceima to protest corruption and other forms of domination by the state.

Agricultural workers in the province of Aitka Baha have carried out a labor march in which they protest against not receiving their rights, restriction on trade union activity, and unfairness of the authorities towards employers. They renewed their demands to improve the general conditions of work, including raising the minimum wage and taking care of their living conditions.

Azilal nurses protested for three months in front of the Ministry of Health headquarters in Malal to demand improved conditions. The statement said that they ended the sit-in in response to the calls of a number of activists who showed solidarity with the justice of our request, after the inclusion the demands on the agenda of the meeting of the National Committee of the Transitional Movement of the Ministry of Health held at the Ministry of Health in Rabat on Tuesday 11 July 2017 and the promise to meet the demands.
300 to 450 people went to the streets in Rabat to support the 5000 people that protested in al Hoceima.
5000 people protested in al Hoceima.

column17: Security forces attacked the Congress of the Moroccan trade union confederation UGTM held at ""Zenit"" conference hall in Riyadh district of Rabat, and tried to ban it. However the participants were able to beak the ban, as they bypassed the security forces and entered the hall, before the security personnel stormed the room afterwards to stop the continuation of the congress. As a result of this intrusion, there was a clash between the security and the attendees in the hall.

Thousands of people were taking part in a protest march in the town of Targuist, heading to the commune of Sidi Boutemim, about six kilometres away. In the same time, a strike was held in the town. Most shopkeepers and coffee shop owners closed their doors and joined protesters, asking for their claims to be met. Protesters ask for the satisfaction of basic topics concerning the population such as a revision of the electricity bills

Young people went to the streets to support their leader Zefzafi from the Hirak movement. Rioters clashes with police after authorities sought to arrest Zefzafi. 40 people were arrested following these clashes.
Rioters threw rocks at police forces in Ajdir. Security material is stolen by the rioters.
PJD leaders and members of parliament rallied in Casablanca Friday against the ongoing detention of five party members arrested for 'praising terrorism'.
Violent clashes between rioters and the police pursued from Saturday night to Sunday. Police tried to disperse the rioters from marching towards the center while rioters threw stones at the police.

15 people blocked the tramway at Hay Mohmmadi in Casablanca, in protest of the new schedule for Ramadan.The actions this morning stopped traffic in both directions, meaning that trams were delayed for two hours and tens of thousands of commuters were affected. Police later removed the protesters, and trams resumed their service at 9am.
Arrests: Protest leader Nasser Zefzafi was arrested on Monday for ""undermining the security of the state"" and other crimincal acts.

Tensions between rioters and the police happened on Tuesday night. Police tried to prevent the rioters from marching torwards the center but pulled back following a tense but non-violent standoff with the demonstrators.
