The inhabitants of Imintanoute have been protesting for three weeks against a network of sanitation that does not cover the whole city. The local authorities tried to respond favorably to the inhabitants' demands, but the anger of the inhabitants did not go down. There were several hundred demonstrators to take to the streets on 16 June in Imintanout, in the province of Chichaoua. It is unstated whether the protests have been continuous so a time precision of 2 has been put in for the prior week's protests.
Inhabitants of Hoceima carried out a peaceful sit-in without any notable incident.
Inhabitants of Hoceima carried out a general strike in light of the recent developments and clashes with police in the city. Later in the evening inhabitants carried out a protest.

Rioters on the streets of Imzouren threw stones at officers, who in turn used water cannon and charged the protestors in a bid to disperse them and bring down their improvised barricades. Rioters wanted to show solidarity with arrested protest leader Zefzafi.
Inhabitants of Hoceima proceeded with their general strike for a second day in order to protest the arrest of protest-leader Zefzafi. In the evening they carried out a peaceful protest.

A group of students wrecked havoc in one of Fez' High Schools, deeming the Baccalaureate exam they were supposed to take Saturday morning to be ""too difficult,"" and the teacher's guard too ""up tight."" The students broke down the school's utilities, from doors and windows to the classrooms chairs and desks. Even the small gardens inside the school didn't escape their wrath, as they stomped down the plants and broke the garden's pots.
On Sunday, hundreds of demonstrators took part in a ninth straight night of protests in Al-Hoceima and other towns.
On Sunday, hundreds of demonstrators took part in a ninth straight night of protests in Al-Hoceima and other towns in the Rif region, an AFP correspondent said.
On Sunday, hundreds of demonstrators took part in a ninth straight night of protests in Al-Hoceima and other towns.

Rif24.com news outlet, which is based in the Rif region, posted on its Facebook page a live video from a protest that was held on 4 June in the city of Imzouren, near Hoceima. The video, which was viewed over 29,000 times, showed a large crowd in a square chanting: ""Crush the [political] parties who promote illusions.""
Arrests: Two leaders, who overtook the al-Hoceima/Hirak-protest coordination from arrested leader Nasser Zefzafi, were arrested by Moroccan authorities.
Several hundred people from the rif-region went to the street in the night of Monday to Tuesday to continue protests and ask for the liberation of their arrested leaders. No incident was reported.
On Tuesday hundreds of demonstrators took part in a ninth straight night of protests in Al-Hoceima.

The inhabitants of Imintanoute have been protesting for three weeks against a network of sanitation that does not cover the whole city. The local authorities tried to respond favorably to the inhabitants' demands, but the anger of the inhabitants did not go down. There were several hundred demonstrators to take to the streets on 16 June in Imintanout, in the province of Chichaoua. It is unstated whether the protests have been continuous so a time precision of 2 has been put in for the prior week's protests.
Protesters in Hoceima went to the street to protest against the arrest of the protests leaders. Police forces were in place but no clashes took place.

Clashes between rioters and the police broke out in Hoceima. Rioters threw stones at the police while the police tried to disperse protests through using teargas. At least two persons, one rioter and one policeman, were injured.
Clashes between rioters and the police broke out in Imzouren. Rioters threw stones at the police while the police tried to disperse protests through using teargas.
On Saturday around 500 people marched in Imzouren, around 15 kilometres (nine miles) from Al-Hoceima, an AFP photographer said.
Protesters gathered in Al-Hoceima late Saturday without incident. Their numbers were lower than in previous days.
Protesters rallied in Imzourenz to demand the release of protest leader Zefzafi.
Protesters rallied in al Hoceima to demand the release of protest leader Zefzafi.

Thousands of people took to the streets of Rabat Sunday demanding that authorities release the leaders of a protest movement that has rocked Morocco's neglected northern Rif region for months. The demonstrators marched along Mohamed VI avenue in downtown Rabat in a procession nearly a kilometre (less than a mile) long, chanting ""Free the prisoners!"", an AFP correspondent said.

Arrests: A court in Morocco on Wednesday sentenced 25 demonstrators and suspected members of a grassroots protest movement to 18 months in jail each, a defence attorney said. They were among 32 people arrested more than two weeks ago after clashes that erupted in the port of Al-Hoceima when police tried to detain the head of the movement, Nasser Zefzafi.

Nightly clashes between protesters and Moroccan security forces in the flashpoint city of Al-Hoceima over the region's marginalisation are turning more violent. ""They were hitting people. Youths dispersed into sideroads and started throwing stones, while the police used tear gas,"" the source said, adding that women were also attacked and several protesters hurt in running battles.

The inhabitants of Imintanoute have been protesting for three weeks against a network of sanitation that does not cover the whole city. The local authorities tried to respond favorably to the inhabitants' demands, but the anger of the inhabitants did not go down. There were several hundred demonstrators to take to the streets on 16 June in Imintanout, in the province of Chichaoua. It is unstated whether the protests have been continuous so a time precision of 2 has been put in for the prior week's protests.
Police on Monday dispersed a demonstration in the capital Rabat involving human rights activists who had attempted to mobilize in solidarity with Hirak.

Police have arrested three more members of a protest movement in northern Morocco's neglected Rif region, prompting hundreds of demonstrators to rally demanding their release Monday evening in Imzouren.
On 19 June, Lakome reported that protests had continued in a number of northern towns and cities overnight, with hundreds of people taking part and demanding the prisoners' release.

Residents of Morocco's northern city of Al-Hoceima on Thursday beat pots and pans on their rooftops to show solidarity with ongoing popular demonstrations in the restive Al-Rif region.They staged their impromptu demonstration on Thursday to protest the arrest by the Moroccan authorities of dozens of protesters and activists in Al-Rif.
Workers of a mining company protested in front of the company's headquarters in protest against the administration's delay in implementing an agreement signed with workers.

Hundreds of mourners have attended the funeral of Rif protest activist El Mortada Iamrachen's father in Ajdir, near Al Hoceima, on Friday.Mourners marched in procession while the deceased was taken to his burial. Media reports indicated that throughout the march no political chants were heard.However, once the deceased was buried, mourners went in a demonstration to demand the release of Rif protests detainees and denounce the government's attitude towards the region.

Moroccan security forces clashed Monday with demonstrators in Al-Hoceima, activists and witnesses said, a day after King Mohammed VI criticised delays in development in the restive northern city. The clashes erupted after hundreds of demonstrators took to the streets of Al-Hoceima in the late afternoon despite police roadblocks, activists said. Several rioters were injured. Moreover, Al Hoceima authorities said that 39 members of the police were injured after they had been stoned by a ""group of individuals, some of them hooded.""
Moroccan security forces clashed Monday with demonstrators in Ajdir, according to a local journalist, adding that some people were injured and dozen arrested.
In clashes between rioters and police forces in Imzouren around 29 policemen were injured.
People in al Hoceima protested peacefully, banging pots, following clashes with the police the day before.

On Saturday protesters held a demonstration on Sfiha beach in Ajdir, a few kilometers away from Al Hoceima, the epicenter of the eight-month long protests. Pictures and videos published on social and online news outlets show riot police encircling protesters on the beach. According to the reports, protesters stated that they had resorted to organizing the demonstration in the unusual settingdue to the heavy nature of police interventions in the city.

A driver ran over a policeman in Hassan, Rabat, on Monday after a heated argument between the two.It was reported that the police officer was also ""beaten"" by the driver. The unknown assailant was reportedly driving his child to school before he became involved in an argument with the policeman.

Movement of forces: Moroccan security forces have begun withdrawing from the restive northern cities of Al-Hoceima and Imzouren, which have been rocked by weeks of social unrest, officials and residents said .A ""gradual"" pullback from both cities began on Monday at the request of King Mohammed VI, the governor of Al-Hoceima province, Fouad Chourak, told reporters.

Reports of police abuse against Hirak protesters to pressure them to sign self-incriminating confessions. In an investigation released in July, 21 of 53 defendants said that police threatetened to rape them or their families. 17 of them said that they experienced physical violence during interrogation including slapping, beating, punching in the face while they were handcuffed, or that dirty rags were insterted into their mouths.

Organized by women, in support of Silya and other detainees of the Hirak, a demonstration was violently suppressed Saturday in Rabat. As dozens of demonstrators gathered at about in front of Parliament, police intervened to disperse them by force.In a video posted on an information website, police officers are seen shooting the militants from the lawn where they had taken their places and kicking them.

Protests in northern Morocco have continued as activists reported that Nasser Zefzafi, a key leader of the Rif's Hirak (mobilisation) movement, will soon appear before the judiciary.Over the weekend, demonstrators gathered again on Esfiha beach in the north, chanting anti-authorities slogans and expressing solidarity with Zefzafi.

On 12 July, activists gathered outside the court where a famous activist ie being tried, chanting support for ""the people"" of Morocco and holding banners demanding the release of the prisoners of conscience, as shown in a live broadcast on the Facebook page of Hirak News Casablanca.
Dozens of rural people gathered at the municipal offices in Zerarda to protest their living conditions.
200 demonstrators gathered in Rabat to hold a peaceful sit-in in support of the Hirak protesters in Al-Hoceima.

Although authorities had banned a planned protest, protesters gathered in Al Hoceima. The police tried to disperse the crowds with teargas and then fought running battles with the protesters, who threw stones at the police. The government claims that 11 protesters and 72 policemen were injured. One injured protester later died in the hospital.

Dozens of workers from the French Company Cita protested in front of the headquarters of the state of Casablanca against their dismissal, demanding the President of the Council to leave. This comes as Casablanca experiences a crisis in the cleaning sector, leading to fining of companies involved in the sector.

The inhabitants of Imider - a group of seven villages in southeastern Morocco - marched on Aug. 1 to Mount Alebban, where they have been holding a sit-in to reaffirm the demands of their 6-years-old, ongoing protest movement. They demand proper water supply and to profit more from the big silver mine that is located nearby.
186 sub-Saharan African migrants stormed the border bost in Ceuta and were successful in crossing it. Four rioters were taken to the hospital for injuries. One police officer was also injured.

Hundreds of people gathered in Casablanca in a demonstration to mourn the death of Imad El Attabi, the Rif activist who passed away on Tuesday in Rabat's military hospital. On Tuesday night, the demonstrators met in Place Marechal in Morocco's biggest city and lit candles in tribute to the deceased activist, who died as a result of a severe head injury during the July 20 march in Al Hoceima.
Protesters waged a sit-in in commemoration of deceased protester Imad Attabi. The sit-in was dispersed by Moroccan authorities.

Thousands of inhabitants of al Hoceima attended the funeral of deceased Imad Attabi and chanted pro-Hirak movement slogans, honoring the ""martyr"". The march was taking place in the whole city, while in some neighbourhoods small clashes with the police were reported.
Protesters waged a sit-in in front of the parliament in commemoration of deceased protester Imad Attabi.

In the night of 12 to 13 August, protesters clashed with police forces in the city of Al Araoui., Nador province. Police forces intervened to break up a protest over the death of Rif activist Imad Atabi, Moroccan news website Hespress reported. The security services arrested an unknown number of protesters, estimated at around 30 by rights groups. On 14 August, the local branch of the protest movement, known as Hirak, has issued a statement blaming security presence for the clashes.

On 13 August, hundreds of protestors took to the streets of Imzouren in the evening, demanding the release of Hirak prisoners, despite their protest being banned by local authorities. Pro-protest Facebook pages shared images of the protests, saying that they took place despite police forces cutting off access to the city.

The radiologists at the Hassan II University Hospital continue to protest against the ""arbitrary"" measures taken against them, as they were subjected to unfair disciplinary punishment after exercising their constitutional right to strike.

Dozens of farmers from the northern Rahamna region protested this week against the policy of agricultural cooperatives in Rahamna, which excluded them from the agricultural insurance compensation for this season, considered a dry season.
Angry parents went to the streets in Fes' Zawaaga neighborhood to protest against a criminal gang raiding their homes and trying to rape their daughters.
People outside the parliament in Rabat staged a protest against sexual harassment after footage of a woman being assaulted on a bus caused outrage across the North African country.

Hundreds of people staged a protest Wednesday in the Moroccan city of Casablanca against sexual harassment after footage of a woman being assaulted on a bus caused outrage across the North African country.

Following filmmaker Mahmoud Frites' Facebook post inciting his followers to rape Moroccan gay public figure Adam Lahlou, known as ""Adouma,"" the internet celebrity has been harassed, threatened, insulted, and beaten in the streets of Tangier by a group of three men.
A physical altercation broke out between a group of sub-Saharan migrants and members a Moroccan family in the Masnana neighbourhood in Tangier.
Sub-saharan Migrants were fighting with residents of Tangiers Masnana neighbourhood. Security forces intervened after they were informed about the clashes. The migrants were later deported.

Workers of Balearia Company for Maritime Transport organized a protest with The Moroccan Workers' Union against the dismissal of workers by the Ministry of equipment, transport, logistics and water, after it was expected to renew the company's utilisation of the line between Nador and Ameria.

A number of sailors, hoteliers and employees of Moroccan company for commercial navigation ""Comanav"" in Casablanca protested against the non-payment of their dues and compensation after they have been dismissed.

Dozens of construction workers protested at the company responsible for completing the health center project for not paying their wages. According to local sources, the Royal Gendarmerie prevented workers from completing their march towards the center of Tangier city.
Around a dozen of persons staged a sit-in in front of the Court of Appeal in Casablanca to show their support with detainees from the Hirak movement.

Strikes: More than 30 out of 216 detained activists from the Hirak movement went on a hunger strike in different prisons of Morocco. After two weeks of strike detainees who were moved to Casablanca, Fez, Taza and Taourit were particularly affected.

An army colonel was attacked by individuals with covered faces and armed with knives, who then stole an army pick-up truck. It is not determined whether the act had a criminal or political background. Early investigations led by a police unit suggested that the attackers likely belonged to drug- and cigarette-smuggling gangs but it can not be exluded that the Polisario is connected to the attack.

A group of 'Ozone Environment and Services"" workers in Guelmim held a protest in solidarity with one of their colleagues who underwent disadvantegeous treatment by the company after publishing a post on ""Facebook"" critisizing the company.

A number of dismissed workers of the Moroccan Maritime Company Comanav held a protest in front of the headquarters of the General Directorate of this company in Casablanca, demanding an immediate settlement of their administrative and professional status.
Protests took place in the town of Imzouren. Protesters have called for better living conditions and for the release of the detainees.
Inhabitants of Zagora protested against the shortage of water supply in the city.

column8: Police Forces of Morocco (1999-) Prison Guards
column17: A prisoner and an employee died in Toulal 2 prison in Meknes. The prisoner had attempted to take one of the officials of the prison as hostage. Faced with the failure of attempts to neutralize the detainee, a prison official was ""forced"" to fire warning shots. These shots hit the inmate in the legs and hips.The detainee then succumbed to his injuries. An official from the prison of Toulal 2 lost his life during this intervention.

A policeman on traffic duty was assaulted in the northern city of Tetouan by an individual with a bladed weapon. The individual was, according to police, suffering from mental disorders. The suspect attacked the policeman from behind, leading the officer to use his gun. The policeman fired at the attacker, who was wounded in his shoulder but managed to escape arrest. The policeman suffered a serious injury and was transferred to a city hospital.

Twenty-one people have been arrested after a demonstration over shortages of drinking water in a town in south-western Morocco turned violent. Dozens of residents took part in the so-called ""march of thirst"" on 8 October to call for a solution to the ongoing lack of drinking water in some districts of the town of Zagora. The protest was peaceful at first, but reportedly turned violent after a number of youths joined the march. Stones were then thrown at cars, shops and local authorities, rubbish bins were set on fire and roads were blocked, and at least 20 protesters were arrested. Four members of the security forces were injured during the violence.

Up to a thousand protesters came out in the streets of Casablanca to denounce the state's continued detention of rights activists who raised their voice for the marginalized Al-Rif region.During the protest on Sunday, people chanted several slogans ""freedom for all detainees"" and ""people want to fight corruption"".

column7: UNEM: National Union of Moroccan Students; CNCES: National Coordination Committee for Higher Education
column17: Secretary of State for Higher Education was expelled from the Higher Institute of Technology in Casablanca by protesters. The secretary, who is a member of the Justice and Development party [PJD], was surrounded by hundreds of students of the national union of Morocco students and higher education teachers who are members of the national union of higher education, who chanted 'out, out' in front of him.

Around 900 workers from a oil refinery marched from the headquarters of the refinery in the city of Muhammadiyah to the HQs of the Commercial Court, to demand the reopening of the recently closed company.

Employees, syndicalists and other members from the 'FDT: Democratic Federation of Labour' staged a protest-rally in Rabat to denounce disadvantageous policies that were taken against them by different successive governments.
Family members of detained illegal Morrocan immigrants in Libya organised a protest-rally (llikely in Rabat) to call on the King to intervene in the fate of their children and relatives.
People in Zagora protested against the insufficient supply of water in the city.
Relatives from prisoners from the Hirak Movement protested in front of the Oukacha Prison in Casablanca.

A train traveling from Tangier to Casablanca caught fire between Sale and Sidi Bouknadel, leading passengers outraged with the National Railways treatment of the situation to block the train tracks by standing for about an hour.
Around a hundred of unemployed university graduates in Laayoune in Western Sahara have raised signs on the roofs of their houses in protest against unemployment.

Workers at the Skasawa mines, in the province of Chishawah, decided to strike and protest at the exit of Imantanut city to denounce nonpayment of salaries for two months. Police forces initially prevented workers from reaching the place but protesters used taxis to reach the scene to be able to march in Imintanoute.

Small protests took place in Al Hoceima & Imzouren to prepare for the commemoration of the death of fisherman Mohcine Fikri one year ago. The protests were immediately dispersed by police and protesters arrested.

Small protests took place in Al Hoceima & Imzouren to prepare for the commemoration of the death of fisherman Mohcine Fikri one year ago. The protests were immediately dispersed by police and protesters arrested.
Dozens of teachers staged a protest rally outside the provincial directorate of education in Meknes calling for an amendment of primary schools timetables in the commune of Wislan.
Protests took place in Rabat to commemorate the 1-year anniversary of Mohcine Fikris death which led to unrest in the Rif region.

Security forces imposed a lock-down and made some arrests after skirmishes with residents in al-Hoceima on the day of the anniversary of Mouhcine Fikri's death. Two brothers of the dead Fikri were reportedly arrested during the riots.
Protests took place in Casablanca to commemorate the 1-year anniversary of Mohcine Fikris death which led to unrest in the Rif region.

column7: BDS: Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions Movement
column17: Boycott, Divestment & Sanctions (BDS) activists were arrested by police forces after protesting against the participation of an Israeli firm in the international date festival in Erfoud, Southeast Morocco.

Police Forces in Taourirt prevented workers who were dismissed from a coal factory from completing a protest march from Oujda to Rabat. When protesters arrived in Taourirt the police prevented them from continuing the march. Workers in the city went on a hunger strike and 3 of them had to be taken to the hospital.

After the funeral of a deceased citizen, rioters marched from Bni Drar to the seat of the prefecture in Bni Khaled which they attacked with stones before blocking the circulation at the National Highway 2, connecting Oujda with Nador. They also entered the communal depot in Bani Khaled and set vehicles on fire before smashing several shops and bus stations in the city. Security forces then intervened to stop the rioting.

The guards and cleaners at a regional hospital in Al Hoceima organized a protest inside the regional hospital's courtyard against a series of measures taken by the hospital administration, such as arbitrary dismissal and forcing them do work not foreseen in their job description.

Inhabitants from Tamtetoucht started a month-long sit-in in front of Toudgha dam in Tinghir province. They denounce the fact that they will not profit sufficiently from the dam with regards to irrigation.
Protesters in Essaouria demonstrate in solidarity with the 15 women killed in Sidi Boulaalam by a stampede during the distribution of supplies.
Protesters in Casablanca demonstrate in solidarity with the 15 women killed in Sidi Boulaalam by a stampede during the distribution of supplies.
Ozone cleaning workers marched to protest against salary cuts. The protest was dispersed by the police.

column7: ASCOMS: Platform of Sub-Saharan Communities and Associations in Morocco
column17: The Platform of Sub-Saharan Associations and Communities in Morocco (ASCOMS) organized on Thursday in Rabat, a sit-in protest in front of the embassy of Libya over the revalations of slavery in the country
Moroccan rioters burn down the temporary tents and accommodation of Sub-Saharan migrants
Several young Moroccans and sub-Saharans clashed with stones near the Boulevard La Croix de Casablanca. Vehicles and property is burnt during the clashes
Relatives of some 200 Moroccans held in Libya for attempting to emigrate to Italy demonstrated in Rabat

column7: Police Forces of Morocco (1999-) Prison Guards
column17: 01 December. In Al Alyoun, two human rights defenders were detained and tortured by Moroccan police.

column7: UMT: Moroccan Workers Union; UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers; UNTM: National Union of Moroccan Labour
column17: Teaching personnel from three syndicates organised a protest march in Rabat to protest against ongoing physical aggressions against them.
The workers of a textile factory organised a massive demonstration in Fes against bad social conditions and incertainty about the future of the factory.
Altercations erupted between Moroccan young people from Derb Lekbir neighborhood and sub-Saharan migrants from a camp in Casablanca.
Inhabitants from Rabat, Oujda, Berkane and Nador protested to denounce US president Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israels capital.
Inhabitants from Rabat, Oujda, Berkane and Nador protested to denounce US president Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israels capital.
Inhabitants from Rabat, Oujda, Berkane and Nador protested to denounce US president Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israels capital.
Inhabitants from Rabat, Oujda, Berkane and Nador protested to denounce US president Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israels capital.

A police officer was injured in clashes between sub-Saharan migrants and police forces. The migrants had tried to escape from their camp in Casablanca because they were threatened to be deported to Dakhla in Southern Morcco.
Tens of thousands of protesters rallied in Morocco's capital Rabat as demonstrations against US President Donald Trump's declaration of Jerusalem as Israel's capital continued to spread.

Movement of forces: The Polisario Front reportedly conducted military exercises in the Guerguerat buffer strip between Mauritania and Morocco. This is the first time the Polisario Front was seen in the area since it's UN-accorded withdrawal on April 27.

Workers and trade unionists of the Democratic Confederation of Labour (CDT) held a protest against their arbitrary dismissal by 'Citta Blanca' company, responsible for the cleaning sector in Casablanca.

Thousands of people protested in Jerada against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine. The demonstrators have adopted the slogans of the Al-Hirak al-Shaabi movement that staged a string of protests this year in the neighbouring Rif region.
Teenagers protested in Imzouren to denounce a lack of opportunities. They have been arrested the following day and now face trial over participation in a non-authorised protest.

Thousands of people protested in Jerada against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine. The demonstrators have adopted the slogans of the Al-Hirak al-Shaabi movement that staged a string of protests this year in the neighbouring Rif region. Security forces dispersed the protest.

Fighting erupted between security forces in Rabat and dozens of African migrants near the 'Gammera' station after that hundreds of Africans had been camping in the'Gammera' forest for months.

Thousands of people protested in Jerada against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine. The demonstrators have adopted the slogans of the Al-Hirak al-Shaabi movement that staged a string of protests this year in the neighbouring Rif region.

Movement of forces: The Polisario Front was present in the demilitarised zone in Guerugerat. They established a checkpoint for some hours where they intercepted a race vehicle participating in the Rally Desert Challenge. They conducted military operations near the Guerguerat strip zone a weekly earlier.
Janitors in Casablanca organised a protest to denounce the company's delay in paying their salaries.
Thousands of people continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine.

Air traffic safety technicians organized a car demonstration towards the Royal Palace in Rabat which led to traffic jams and interruption in airport operations. They denounce their bad socio-economic conditions.

column8: Military forces of Spain (2016-2018) Civil Guard
column17: On Jan 06, over 200 African migrants stormed the border fence at Melilla. 209 migrants managed to enter the enclave, in an effort that saw the injury of four migrants and of one Spanish Civil Guard.
People from Outat el Haj (Boulemene) protested against the deficient state of health services in the city after a street vendor died in an ambulance.
Casablanca's taxi drivers organised a protest march against what they call the ""unfair competition"" of Uber and Careem.
Police forces violently dispersed a sit-in by people from Tamtetoucht in front of Toudgha dam in Tinghir province. Several protesters were injured.
Inhabitants of Fes went to the streets to protest against a French citizen that had molested two underage girls. They demand the highest judicial sentence for him.

Moroccan health unions and a number of associations have held protests in several cities, asking for the acquittal of a nurse, who is sentenced to three months of imprisonment and a fine. Protesters consider the ruling unjust.

Moroccan health unions and a number of associations have held protests in several cities, asking for the acquittal of a nurse, who is sentenced to three months of imprisonment and a fine. Protesters consider the ruling unjust.

Thousands of people from Jerada marched to Hassi Blal to protest against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine some weeks ago.
People from Outat el Haj (Boulemene) protested against the deficient state of health services in the city after a street vendor died in an ambulance.
Thousands of people continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine some weeks ago.
Workers and journalists of Morocco's second channel organized a protest in front of the headquarters in Ain el-Sabaa in Casablanca to denounce the mismanagement of the channel by the directorate.
Thousands of people continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine some weeks ago.
Thousands of people continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after two young men died while digging in an abandoned coal mine some weeks ago.
Four Moroccans were injured in a stampede when rioters tried to force their way through the Melilla border post. Contrary to what has been reported, no death was recorded.
People from Outat el Haj (Boulemene) protested against the deficient state of health services in the city after a street vendor died in an ambulance.
Journalists and activists protested outside a court in Rabat in support of four journalists being tried for publishing content deemed confidential.
Secondary Education teachers protested in Ouarzazate to call for an improvement in their working conditions.
Thousands of people continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after the third person died, within several weeks, while digging in a coal mine.
Inhabitants of Hassi Bellal near Jerada staged a sit-in against economic marginalisation after a third person died, within several weeks, while digging in a coal mine.
Thousands of people continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after the third person died, within several weeks, while digging in a coal mine.
Thousands of people continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after the third person died, within several weeks, while digging in a coal mine.

column7: SIMSP: Independent Syndicate of Public Service Medical Workers
column17: On 10 February, public sector doctors held a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Health in Rabat to demand salary and bonus increases, as well as additional medical staff in order to better accomodate patients.

Citizens continued protesting in Jerada against economic marginalisation after the third person died, within several weeks, while digging in a coal mine. Protesters call for a meeting with the governor from Oriental-governorate after PM Othmani announced measures to calm the dissatisfaction.

column7: CDT: Democratic Confederation of Labour; Teachers (Morocco)
column17: Education workers protested in front of the regional directorates at the invitation of the National Union of Education affiliated with the Democratic Confederation of Labour(CDT) as part of a 24-hour strike.

column7: CDT: Democratic Confederation of Labour; Teachers (Morocco)
column17: Education workers protested in front of the regional directorates at the invitation of the National Union of Education affiliated with the Democratic Confederation of Labour(CDT) as part of a 24-hour strike.

column7: CDT: Democratic Confederation of Labour; Teachers (Morocco)
column17: Education workers protested in front of the regional directorates at the invitation of the National Union of Education affiliated with the Democratic Confederation of Labour(CDT) as part of a 24-hour strike.
Workers from 'Ouislane environnement' company physically blocked a truck in front of the HQs of the company.

Citizens organised a protest in Jerada against economic marginalisation after several workers died during their work in mines. Police blocked protesters but no clashes were reported. Inhabitants are not satisfied with developmental promises made by PM Othmani during his visit to Ouajda on 10 February.

Citizens organised a protest in Jerada against economic marginalisation after several workers died during their work in mines. Inhabitants are not satisfied with developmental promises made by PM Othmani during his visit to Ouajda on 10 February.

Citizens organised a sit-in in Jerada against economic marginalisation after several workers died during their work in mines. Inhabitants are not satisfied with developmental promises made by PM Othmani during his visit to Ouajda on 10 February.

On 2 March, phosphate workers in Khouribga held a protest in front of their workplace to ask for engaging in a dialogue with the administration in order to meet their demands of improving their socio-economic conditions. The protest was called for by the CDT.

On 2 March technicians working in a number of sectors in Morocco decided to organize national strikes and a protest in front of the Ministry of Administrative Reform and the Civil Service to protest against the government's non-response to improve their socio-economic conditions.
On 3 March, agents of national self-help institutions carried out a massive march in Rabat to call for an improvement of their professional situation.

On 4 March, workers from Gilmarfer company in Casablanca carried out a protest against the deteriorating working conditions. Security forces were present but did not clash or intervene with the protest.

On 4 March, residents of Jerada marched through the streets of the city chanting slogans calling for an economic alternative for the town to prevent the unemployed from resorting to digging for coal in disused mines.

On 5 March, residents of Jerada marched through the streets of the city for the second consecutive day chanting slogans calling for an economic alternative for the town to prevent the unemployed from resorting to digging for coal in disused mines.

On 6 March, residents of Jerada marched through the streets of the city for the third consecutive day chanting slogans calling for an economic alternative for the town to prevent the unemployed from resorting to digging for coal in disused mines.
On 7 March, workers of the oil refinery 'Samir' organised a protest march in Rabat after the refinery was put up for sale three years ago and did not reopen its doors yet.
Inhabitants of Jerada staged a spontaneous sit-in in front of the police station to denounce the arrest of one of the protest's leaders, Mustapha Dainine, the same day.

On 10 March Moroccan authorities have arrested two leaders, Amine Mkallech and Mustapaha Dainane, of the protest movement that began last December in Jerada. Dainine and Mqallech reported that police forces kicked them on their heads, backs, and necks while arresting them. The arrests led to a new wave of protests in Morocco.
On 10 March, the Istiqlal (independence)-party organised a protest in Imrouzen to call for the release of Rif activists.

On 13 March, citizens organised a sit-in in Jerada, defying a government ban on holding demonstrations announced the same day. When police forces tried to rescue four demonstrators that jumped into a pit without a rope, rioters threw stones at police leading to skirmishes and injuries among security forces.

On 14 March, hundreds of rioters clashed with Moroccan police during a march in Jerada, defying a government ban on holding demonstrations announced a day earlier. Rioters set police cars on fire and wounded a number of policemen while police used teargas. Nine rioters were detained.
On 16 March, inhabitants in Jerada protested again to call for economic development and release of protest leaders.
Around 16 March, police forces arrested several dozens of protesters from Jerada and reportedly beat up several of them during the arrests.
On 17 March, inhabitants in Jerada protested to call for economic development and release of protest leaders.
On 18 March, rioters in Jerada set cars on fire and threw stones on distant policemen to call for economic development and release of protest leaders.

On 26 March, workers of Al-Minzah Hotel gathered in Tangier to protest against the administration's decision to close the institution under the pretext of carrying out reforms without informing the workers in advance.

Non-violent activity: Between March 22 and April 7, the Moroccan Royal Armed Forces carried out military exercises dubbed 'Tafilalet 2018' in the southeastern city of Errachidia to deter escalation east of Morocco's defense wall with the Polisario Front.
Movement of forces: On 29 March, Polisario Front elements reportedly got close to Moroccan soldiers near the separation wall and hurled stones on them, also placing their flag on the wall.

Looting: On 29 March, fourteen members of the Polisario Front raided Al Mahbes, a restricted area in Morocco close to the Algerian border. They also set up tents in the Assa Zag and Semara regions (Tifariti, Bir Lehlou and Mahbes) in violation of the UN 1991 ceasefire resolution. The UN says that they have not recorded violations of the ceasefire agreement.

Around 29 March, inhabitants from the Tindouf refugee camp who were searching for gold in Mijik, the Moroccan Sahara, near the Mauritanian town of Zouerate were hunted, abused and robbed by the Polisario Front. They say that they have been tortured and beaten.

On 9 April, a number of rights activists protested in front of the Oujda court, calling for the release of the detainees, that have received sentences of imprisonment between six months and one and a half years.
Movement of Forces: Around 9 April, Moroccan army reportedly sent troops and reinforcements to deter any movements by the Polisario Front in the demilitarised zone.

On 18 April, a journalist from Akhbar al-Youm, Fatima Zohra Rajmi, was hit and injured by a lawyer in the court of appeal in Casablanca while covering the trial of Taoufik Bouachrine, the director of Akhbar al Youm.

On 20 April, dozens of workers of Samir refining company organised a protest in front of the headquarter in Muhammadiya to ask the government to resume the production of the refinery to save ist production units from erosion and fading.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers; CDT: Democratic Confederation of Labour; UNTM: National Union of Moroccan Labour; Health Workers (Morocco)
column17: On April 24, nurses and health technicians, headed by the Moroccan Union of Labour, the General Union of Workers in Morocco and the Democratic Confederation of Labour went on a nation-wide strike and organised protests in front of the regional directorates of the Ministry of Health.

column17: On April 24, nurses and health technicians, headed by the Moroccan Union of Labour, the General Union of Workers in Morocco and the Democratic Confederation of Labour went on a nation-wide strike and organised protests in front of several regional directorates of the Ministry of Health in regional capitals.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers; CDT: Democratic Confederation of Labour; UNTM: National Union of Moroccan Labour; Health Workers (Morocco)
column17: On April 24, nurses and health technicians, headed by the Moroccan Union of Labour, the General Union of Workers in Morocco and the Democratic Confederation of Labour went on a nation-wide strike and organised protests in front of the regional directorates of the Ministry of Health.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers; CDT: Democratic Confederation of Labour; UNTM: National Union of Moroccan Labour; Health Workers (Morocco)
column17: On April 24, nurses and health technicians, headed by the Moroccan Union of Labour, the General Union of Workers in Morocco and the Democratic Confederation of Labour went on a nation-wide strike and organised protests in front of the regional directorates of the Ministry of Health.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers; CDT: Democratic Confederation of Labour; UNTM: National Union of Moroccan Labour; Health Workers (Morocco)
column17: On April 24, nurses and health technicians, headed by the Moroccan Union of Labour, the General Union of Workers in Morocco and the Democratic Confederation of Labour went on a nation-wide strike and organised protests in front of the regional directorates of the Ministry of Health.
On 26 April, workers at OPC Group in Khouriba protested in front of the local administration headquarters to ask for a meeting to discuss their demands.
On 29 April, a few hundred young Moroccans from Greenpeace protested in Casablanca to call for an action against fossil energies.

Report of renewed protests on the week of 30 April in Jerada to ask for the release of detainees, who were arrested by authorities on the grounds of their protests. Two protests coded on 30 April and 3 May.

On 1 May, workers in Casablanca marched on the street, raising slogans and banners denouncing the deterioration of the purchasing power of Moroccan workers. They also call for freeing all Jerada detainees.

Report of renewed protests on the week of 30 April in Jerada to ask for the release of detainees, who were arrested by authorities on the grounds of their protests. Two protests coded on 30 April and 3 May.

On 5 June around 2000 workers from Danone Morocco staged a sit-in in Rabat to call on people to stop their boycott of Danone products, indicating that thousands of jobs are in danger because of the boycott. Minister of Governance and General Affairs Daoudi was fired by PM Othmani because he participated in this sit-in.
On 13 May, thousands marched in the streets of Rabat to voice their support for the Palestinian people and to denounce the US decision to relocate its embassy to Jerusalem.
On 19 May, students clashed at a faculty of arts in Agadir. One student died before police intervened to disperse the students. The reason for the clashes is unclear.

On 19 May, nomads and local farmers reportedly clashed with knives and stones in El Gouraani because the nomads used the land of the farmers to feed their cattle. After the gendarmerie arrived quickly at the scene, injuries were prevented.

Movement of forces: On 20 May, the Polisario Front reportedly carried out military movements in the demilitarised zone in Tifariti to commemorate the 45th year since it began its armed struggle and thereby violated the ceasefire.
On the week of 20 May, a group of cargo workers at Beni Ansar port in Nador province protested to call for the regularisation of their pending professional and social status.
On 20 May, thousands of Moroccans marched in the streets of Casablanca to protest the killing of Palestinians at the Gaza border.

On the week of 22 May, a police officer slapped and verbally insulted a scooter driver who begged the officer not to seize his scooter. He was slightly injured. On initiative of the MoI, the police officer later had to apologize to him.
On 22 May, dozens of fasting Muslims attacked some non-fasting Moroccans in Tangiers causing several injuries.

On 23 May, students organised demonstrations in Khouribga to show support for a teacher who was detained after violently assaulting a high school girl. Protesters denounced the court's decision to detain the teacher claiming the girl had provoked the teacher.

column7: UNTM: National Union of Moroccan Labour
column17: On 24 May, workers from Casablanca's Tramway Company protested against what they consider injustice, abuse and violation of their rights by the administration.
On the week of 30 May, unknown masked men attacked a couple in a car accusing them of neglecting the rules of Ramadan. The men beat and lightly injured them.

On 7 June several people in Tangiers shouted 'Get Out Akhannouch' as King Mohammad VI arrived in Tangier to inaugurate the new marine port together with his Minister of Agriculture and Fishing Aziz Akhannouch.

column7: UNMT: National Labour Union of Morocco
column17: On 19 June, workers from the National Union of Local Employees in Tahla of the Moroccan National Trade Union organised a protest outside the collective council's heardquarters to ask for compensation for hard works in polluted environments.

On 26 June, supporters of al-Hoceima protest movement leaders shouted slogans such as ""Long Live the Rif"" as the activists left the court in Casablanca after the ruling on their nine-month trial. Nasser Zefzafi was sentenced to 20 years in jail in first instance. Another 49 activists were sentenced to terms of one to five years along with fines in first instance.
On 26 June, protests were held overnight in al-Hoceima against the first-instance-verdicts against the Hoceima protest movement leaders that range from 1 to 20 years of prison.
On 26 June, rioters in Imzouren burned down a school and demonstrated against the first-instance-verdicts against the Hoceima protest movement leaders that range from 1 to 20 years of prison.

On 27 June, citizens in Agadir protested to decry the heavy sentences given to the Hirak-Rif activists. Several Hoceima-protest movement leaders were recently given prison sentences ranging from 1 to 20 years.

On 27 June, citizens in Casablanca protested to decry the heavy sentences given to the Hirak-Rif activists. Several Hoceima-protest movement leaders were recently given prison sentences ranging from 1 to 20 years.

On 27 June, university students in Nador protested to decry the heavy sentences given to the Hirak-Rif activists. Several Hoceima-protest movement leaders were recently given prison sentences ranging from 1 to 20 years.

On 27 June, several hundred protesters gathered in front of the parliament building in Rabat, waving Berber flags, photos of Zefzafi and banners reading ""Freedom for Hirak detainees"". Several Hoceima-protest movement leaders were recently given prison sentences ranging from 1 to 20 years.

On 1 July, female supporters, among them the mother of protest leader Nasser Zefzafi, held a sit-in in Al-Hoceima to show their solidarity with the imprisoned activists. They called on the makhzen to immediately release all the political prisoners.
On 2 July, a policeman attacked and injured a woman in the markets of Oujda after she reportedly resisted to move her street vending stand.
On 6 July, workers belonging to the National Federation of phosphate workers of the Moroccan Workers Union in Safi held a protest in Safi denouncing bad management of the phosphate companies.

Around 7 July, dozens of workers of Samir refining company organised a protest in front of the headquarter in Muhammadiya to ask the government to resume the production of the refinery to save its production units from erosion and fading.

On 7 July, Moroccan police violently prevented activists from the Hirak movement to protest in support of imprisoned activists. Police forces occupied several strategic locations in Nador during the whole day and prevented any protester from approaching. Several civilians were injured when trying to enter the squares.

On 8 July, football hooligans reportedly set camps of sub-Saharan migrants in Fez on fire. Security forces managed to evacuate the area and extinguish the fire. No injuries were sustained. Other sources speak of accidental fire.

On 8 July, football hooligans reportedly set camps of sub-Saharan migrants in Casablanca (Ouled Ziane bus station) on fire. Security forces managed to evacuate the area and extinguish the fire. No injuries were sustained. Other sources speak of accidental fire. In November 2017, violent clashes between sub-Saharan migrants and a group of Moroccans broke out near the same bus station and resulted in a fire.

On 8 July, several thousand persons protested in Casablanca to condemn the recent severe prison sentences against the Hirak activists from the Rif region. They shouted ""freedom for the political prisoners"", ""long live the people"" and ""this state is corrupt"".

column7: Al-Hirak Movement; Al Adl Wa Al Ihssane; February 20 Movement; Berber Ethnic Group (Morocco)
column17: On 15 July, thousands of people demonstrated in Rabat against the jailing of Hirak leaders and activists. Participating groups were activists from Hirak, Islamist group al-Adl w al-Ihsane, activists from the 20 February movement and Berber groups.
On 22 July, protesters held protests in Figuig to demand a reopening of border crossings to Algeria and the reunion of families split up by its closure.
On 22 July, protesters held protests in Zouj Beghal border crossing to demand a reopening of border crossings to Algeria and the reunion of families split up by its closure.

On 24 July, hundreds of residents of Tiznit marched in solidarity with arrested paediatrician Echafi as his trial proceeded. The doctor was arrested for speaking out against alleged corruption in the hospital in Tiznit.

In August, Moroccan police reportedly rounded up African migrants in Boukhalef and Mesnanatan, injuring numerous people, before they were deported to the South with buses. During one such transfers two Malians died. Fatalities split up into two events.
On 22 August, janitors of the 'Ozone'-company protested in Sale to denounce the company's mismanagement and delay in settling their socio-professional situation.
In the week of 22 August, report of violent attacks and bullying by individuals employed by the Mogador Menara Hotel from outside the hotel on striking workers to stop the workers' strike.
On 22 August, people in Ksar el-Kebir protested to denounce that the government cut off water during Eid al-Adha.
On 22 August, people in Taounate protested to denounce that the government cut off water during Eid al-Adha.
On 22 August, people in Ait Milk protested to denounce that the government cut off water during Eid al-Adha.
On 22 August, people in Tinjdad protested to denounce that the government cut off water during Eid al-Adha.
In the week of 28 August, residents in Figuig protested against the lack of tap water in the city.
In the week of 28 August, residents in Talsint protested against the lack of tap water in the city.

column7: CNCV: National Coordination of Contractual Teachers
column17: On 29 August, thousands of contractual professors participated in a mass rally in Rabat following the call of the 'National Coordination of Teachers'. They ask for the drop of contracts and their integration into the public service system for a stable employment situation.
On 31 August, Moroccan police violently dispersed a protest by Rif activists in Nador. Some protesters were injured. A lecturer was arrested and then released.
On 1 September, unemployed graduates from Bouarfa protested in front of the governor's seat. They were attacked by police forces, injuring two protesters who were transferred to the hospital.
On 1 September, recently fired security agents staged a sit-in to denounce their deteriorating living conditions in Bouarfa.
On the weekend of 2 August, African migrants protested outside the prosecutor's office in Tangiers but were blocked by police.

On 4 September, Moroccan nurses and health technicians launched a national strike and protested in front of the ministry of health on the first day, denouncing their deteriorating socio-economic conditions.

Arrests: On or before September 6th, security services (coded here as police) arrested three individuals suspected of being members of an IS cell, in the cities of Tetouan and Agadir (coordinate for Tetouan used).

On 25 September, the Moroccan navy opened fire at a speedboat carrying 20 illegal Moroccan migrants in the Mediterranean sea, off the coast of M'diq-Fnideq, leaving a Moroccan woman killed and three others wounded, including one seriously.
On 28 September, police demolished informal housing in the Sidi Moumen and Ain Sebaa slums in Casablanca and expelled the inhabitants by force without any notice.
On 28 September, the local football club in Tetouan protested following the death of a young woman on a boat shot by Moroccan navy in the Mediterranean sea.

On October 7th, blind students gathered on the rooftop of the Ministry of Family, Solidarity and Social Development in Rabat, to highlight the lack of employment opportunities for those with visual impairments. One protester tragically fell from the roof of the building and died instantly, provoking outrage over the Ministry's handling of the protest and the demands of the protesters.
On Oct 09, the Moroccan navy opened fire at a boat carrying illegal Moroccan migrants in the Mediterranean sea, off the coast of Larache, leaving one of the passengers injured.

In the month of October, the Royal Moroccan Army reported an incident in which their guard sholdiers were shot at along the southern part of the berm in subsector Tichla, which is controlled by the Frente Polisario military. The Frente Polisario denied any involvement or presence in those locations. One soldier was injured.
On October 16th, hundreds gathered in Casablanca to protest corruption in the government. Those protesting included members of unions and NGOs.

column9: Military forces of Spain (2018-2020) Civil Guard
column17: On Oct 21, over 300 African migrants stormed the border fence at Melilla. Moroccan authorities reportedly arrested 141 migrants, while 208 managed to enter Melilla. 13 Moroccan soldiers, 6 Spanish Civil Guards and 19 migrants were reported injured, while 2 migrants were reported killed (one on Moroccan soil and the other on Spanish soil), at least one of which in a suspected heart attack.
Mid-October-18 December: ""boat owners"" in Guerguerat held an open sit-in near the Guerguerat border crossing to protest against the refusal of local officials to grant them fishing licenses.

column7: Labour Group (Morocco); UNMT: National Labour Union of Morocco
column17: On Oct 25, a number of Moroccan workers from the national workers' union took to the streets in front of the Ministry of Equipment, Transport, Logistics and Water in the capital Rabat, to denounce their living conditions.

Over Oct 25 and 26, a number of passengers protested on rails following repeated delays on the Casablanca-Kenitra line. On Oct 25, access at least to the Casablanca-Port train station was blocked; on Oct 26, access t at least the Skhirat, Temara and Bouznika stations were blocked. Police interventions were reported in all locations to disperse demonstrators.

Over Oct 25 and 26, a number of passengers protested on rails following repeated delays on the Casablanca-Kenitra line. On Oct 25, access at least to the Casablanca-Port train station was blocked; on Oct 26, access t at least the Skhirat, Temara and Bouznika stations were blocked. Police interventions were reported in all locations to disperse demonstrators.

Over Oct 25 and 26, a number of passengers protested on rails following repeated delays on the Casablanca-Kenitra line. On Oct 25, access at least to the Casablanca-Port train station was blocked; on Oct 26, access t at least the Skhirat, Temara and Bouznika stations were blocked. Police interventions were reported in all locations to disperse demonstrators.

Over Oct 25 and 26, a number of passengers protested on rails following repeated delays on the Casablanca-Kenitra line. On Oct 25, access at least to the Casablanca-Port train station was blocked; on Oct 26, access t at least the Skhirat, Temara and Bouznika stations were blocked. Police interventions were reported in all locations to disperse demonstrators.

On Oct 26, a number of workers for Nestle Morocco in Al Jadida city staged a protest in front of the group's social and administrative HQs in the Casa nearshore area of Casablanca (located in Oulad Lahsene neighbourhood), to denounce the refusal to hear the trade union's demands (ie. better working conditions and housing grants).

On Oct 26, Moroccan security forces reportedly arrested an engineering student who had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State and was preparing to conduct a suicide attack. The arrest took place in the coastal city of Mohammadia.
On or around Nov 7, students staged a march in Fes to condemn the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round and call on the government to move back to GMT.

On both Nov 8 and Nov 9, students took to the streets of the cities of Beni Mellal, Khenifra, Errachidia and Casablanca to condemn the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round and call on the government to move back to GMT.

On both Nov 8 and Nov 9, students took to the streets of the cities of Beni Mellal, Khenifra, Errachidia and Casablanca to condemn the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round and call on the government to move back to GMT.

On Nov 9, students took to the streets of Marrakech, Meknes, Sale and Kelaat Sraghna to condemn the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round and call on the government to move back to GMT.

On Nov 9, students took to the streets of Marrakech, Meknes, Sale and Kelaat Sraghna to condemn the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round and call on the government to move back to GMT.

On Nov 9, students took to the streets of Marrakech, Meknes, Sale and Kelaat Sraghna to condemn the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round and call on the government to move back to GMT.
On Nov 10, hundreds of students took to the streets in Marrakech to protest against the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round.
On Nov 11, dozens of students took to the streets in front of the parliament in Rabat to protest against the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round.
On Nov 11, hundreds of protesters from the Marrakech region gathered in Essaouira to denounce public policies as hostile toward public freedoms, fundamental rights and the working class.

On Nov 12, students took to the streets in a number of cities across Morocco to protest against the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round. Protests took place in Rabat, Sale, Casblanca, Mohammedia, Migen Taznit, El Kelaa des Sraghna, Temera, Sidi Suleiman, Taza, Zakoura, Azilal, Agadir, Ait Melloul, Khouribga, Driouch, Nador, Tangier and Meknes.

On Nov 12, students took to the streets in a number of cities across Morocco to protest against the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round. Protests took place in Rabat, Sale, Casblanca, Mohammedia, Migen Taznit, El Kelaa des Sraghna, Temera, Sidi Suleiman, Taza, Zakoura, Azilal, Agadir, Ait Melloul, Khouribga, Driouch, Nador, Tangier and Meknes.

On Nov 12, students took to the streets in a number of cities across Morocco to protest against the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round. Protests took place in Rabat, Sale, Casblanca, Mohammedia, Migen Taznit, El Kelaa des Sraghna, Temera, Sidi Suleiman, Taza, Zakoura, Azilal, Agadir, Ait Melloul, Khouribga, Driouch, Nador, Tangier and Meknes.

On Nov 12, students took to the streets in a number of cities across Morocco to protest against the government's decision to stay on GMT+1 all year-round. Protests took place in Rabat, Sale, Casblanca, Mohammedia, Migen Taznit, El Kelaa des Sraghna, Temera, Sidi Suleiman, Taza, Zakoura, Azilal, Agadir, Ait Melloul, Khouribga, Driouch, Nador, Tangier and Meknes.
On Nov 16, Moroccan trade unionists held a protest in Tangier to denounce the treatment of unionists by the Delphi and Volkswagen groups.
On Nov 22, workers from the Ozone company staged a protest in Taourirt to denounce restrictions on trade union activity by the company's management. Police intervened and arrested 10 workers.
25 November: Disabled people in Tizni begin an open sit-in to demand the completion of their files. The sit-in was reported to be ongoing as of 12 December.

On 30 November, a worker violently attacked the UMT general secretary in one of the agricultural farms of Awlad Ben Hammadi in the suburbs of Sidi Slimane because she participated in the trade union strike.
On 2 December, Moroccan pharmacists from the pharmacists union protested in Casablanca to call for a regulation of opening and closing hours and other regulations.

On December 3, car rental owners and employees wearing yellow vests inspired by protesters in France, staged a protest in Marrakech in response ot what they deemd to be the failure of the government to respond to the demands of the sector in particular concerning insurance company fees and taxes.
On December 3, students and parents in Aourir stopped buses demanding that the bus company provides regular traffic for school transports during rush hours.

On December 3, dozens of people with disabilities staged a protest in front of the parliament building in Rabat demanding the king to intervene to solve what they deemed to be a fragile situation, they also called for the dissolution of the government.
On December 3, train passengers prevented trains from passing through the railway station in Bouskoura for three hours in protest against overcrowding.

On 4 December, employees of the regional directorate of taxation protested in front of the Ministry of Public Service in Temara to express their discontent regarding deteriorating socio-economic conditions. The National Authority of Technicians and the National Federation for Administrators had called for the strike. Protesters went on a two-day strike.

On December 4, residents in the Hajj Abbas area of El Jadida barricaded the main road preventing traffic, in protest against the social council not responding to the demands to install signs or a concrete barrier to prevent accidents.
On December 4, residents and foreign tourists in Merzouga staged a protest in response to the poor health services and the absence of a doctor in the area since May.

On 4 December, Moroccan police violently dispersed protests by Sahrawi activists in El-Ayoune and Boujdour. Police arrested two sahrawi journalists and several human rights activists. No report of injury.

On 4 December, Moroccan police violently dispersed protests by Sahrawi activists in El-Ayoune and Boujdour. Police arrested two sahrawi journalists and several human rights activists. No report of injury.
On December 7, Moroccan intelligence dismantled an alleged Islamic State-linked cell composed of six members in Beni Mellal.

On December 7, market traders in Oulad Teima staged a protest in order to draw attention from the authorities due to what they considered to be marginalization of the market casued by increase of goods in supermarkets and shops, however the protests resulted in the cancellation of a visit of a delegation for a project in the industrial area of the town.

10 December: Disabled people in Tizni continue their open sit-in to demand the completion of their files. The sit-in was reported to have begun on November 25th and to still be ongoing as of 12 December. On 10 December, with the order of the chairman of the council, police attempted to disperse the protesters violently, leaving at least one person injured.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights
column17: On 10 December 2018, the Moroccan Association for Human Rights in Tangier organized a protest in the Palais des Nations to mark the International Human Rights Day.

On 12 December 2018, some organized political and civil bodies held a protest in Marrakech condemning the hosting of the international symposium on ""holocaust and its integration into education programs in Morocco and the countries of the Islamic world "" which took place on 10 December 2018.
On or around 13 December 2018, some people in Sidi Boutayeb protested against the reluctance of the authorities to solve the problem of land rights.

column7: UNIM: National Union of Moroccan Engineers
column17: On 14 December 2018, the Vocational Training Sector of the National Union of Moroccan Engineers organized a protest in front of the General Directorate of the Vocational Training Office.

On 16 December 2018, some teachers held a protest in front of the Regional Academy of Education and Training in Rabat against the requirements for promotion. They announced they would go on a strike for three days in early January.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights
column17: On 16 December 2018, the ""Follow-Up Committee on the Recommendations of the National Debate on Gross Violations of Human Rights"" organized a protest in Rabat and called for the respect of human rights and implementation of the recommendations of the Equity and Reconciliation Commission. The Committee is composed of different human rights organizations, including AMDH.

column16: Morocco World News; Maghreb Arabe Presse; AP
column17: On 17 December 2018, the bodies of two female foreign tourists killed by alleged IS supporters were found near Imlil. More than 20 people were arrested.

On 17 December 2018, thousands of employees of private and public sectors organized a protest in Rabat to demand better pay and improved living conditions. Some of them wore yellow vests in reference to the French movement against president Macron.
On 19 December 2018, ""contract teachers"" organized protests in the cities of Rabat, Casablanca, Zagora, Agadir, Ouarzazat and Tangier to demand official integration into the public service.
On 19 December 2018, ""contract teachers"" organized protests in the cities of Rabat, Casablanca, Zagora, Agadir, Ouarzazat and Tangier to demand official integration into the public service.
On 19 December 2018, ""contract teachers"" organized protests in the cities of Rabat, Casablanca, Zagora, Agadir, Ouarzazat and Tangier to demand official integration into the public service.
On 19 December 2018, ""contract teachers"" organized protests in the cities of Rabat, Casablanca, Zagora, Agadir, Ouarzazat and Tangier to demand official integration into the public service.
On 19 December 2018, ""contract teachers"" organized protests in the cities of Rabat, Casablanca, Zagora, Agadir, Ouarzazat and Tangier to demand official integration into the public service.
On 19 December 2018, small taxi owners in Oujda protested against the large number of big urban taxis and the government's non-intervention to resolve the situation.

column7: UGTM: General Union of Moroccan Workers; Labour Group (Morocco)
column17: On 19 December 2018, hundreds of Moroccan officials from public institutions responded to the call of the General Union of Moroccan Workers and took part in a mass protest in Rabat against government oppression and its lack of attention to public administration.
On 19 December 2018, ""contract teachers"" organized protests in the cities of Rabat, Casablanca, Zagora, Agadir, Ouarzazat and Tangier to demand official integration into the public service.
On 21 December 2018, several people held a sit-in in the Gueliz neighborhood in Marrakech to stand in solidarity with the victims of the attack near Imlil.
On 22 December 2018, people gathered in Imlil to condemn the killing of two tourists in Morocco and stand in solidarity with their families.
Over the weekend of 22 December 2018, several marches were organized in various cities in Morocco, including Essaouira and Tangier to denounce the killing of the two Scandinavian tourists near Imlil.
Over the weekend of 22 December 2018, several marches were organized in various cities in Morocco, including Essaouira and Tangier to denounce the killing of the two Scandinavian tourists near Imlil.
On 22 December 2018, a sit-in was held in Agadir in solidarity with the families of the two Scandinavian tourists killed near Imlil .
On 22 December 2018, Marrakech tourist guides organized a sit-in in Jamaa El Fna in Marrakech to denounce the murder of two young Scandinavian tourists near Imlil.
On 22 December 2018, dozens of Moroccan citizens gathered in front of the Norwegian and Danish embassies in Rabat to denounce the killing of tourists in Imlil.

On 23 December 2018, a peaceful march was organized in Imlil in the province of Al-Haouz, in solidarity with the families of the two Scandinavian tourists killed near the area. It was organized by the association Dar Imma, the Moroccan Jewish community, the Church of the Holy Martyrs in Marrakech and the ten communes of Amzmiz.
On or around 23 December 2018, people gathered in Taroudant to stand in solidarity with the families of the victims of the attack near Imlil.

On 23 or 24 December 2018, the Democratic Federation of Labour organized a protest in Biougra to protest the deteriorating social conditions in the region. Protesters clashed with dozens of police forces who were trying to block their way.

On 24 December 2018, several families from Sidi Abdallah Ghiat in the province of Al Haouz entered an open sit-in in front of the seat of the Marrakech-Safi district to demand justice against a real estate company.
Reported on 24 December 2018, a protest was held by land owners in Laayayda in the city of Sale to demand a construction permit.

On 24 December 2018, dozens of protesters from the Salaliat community gathered in front of the government's headquarter in Taroudant holding pictures of their dead relatives who participated in the struggle for land and died without the return of their rights.
On 24 December 2018, a mass rally was held at Bab Bou Jeloud in Fes in solidarity with the families of the Scandinavian tourists whe were killed near Imlil and to condemn their killing.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights
column17: On 25 December 2018, the Tetouan branch of Morrocan Association of Human Rights organized a protest in front of the Court of Appeal in Fes to demand that the the leader of the Justice and Development Party get the maximum penalty for the murder of the leftist student, Ait Al-Jad Mohammed Benaissa.
On or around 26 December 2018, a number of Moroccans staged a silent protest in front of the Catholic Church in Place Al-Joulane in Rabat to denounce the killing of the two tourists near Imlil.

column7: SNSP: National Union of Public Health
column17: On 26 December 2018, the regional office of the National Union of Public Health in Berrechid organized a protest in front of the Health Directorate headquarter in the city to denounce the attacks on medical facilities in the region.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights
column17: On 30 December 2018, a car protest was organized by the Moroccan Association for Human Rights from the city of Ait Melloul to the province of Chtouka Ait Baha in protest against the violation of the rights of agricultural workers.

The protest changed from peaceful to direct confrontation with the herders during which more than ten persons were injured. Police had to intervene to disperse the protesters and calm the situation.

On 7 January 2019, the residents of Douar Ibarkanene in Hassi Berkane entered an open sit-in for the third time in the community headquarter to protest against the delay in repairing the road in their area.

column7: AMDH: Moroccan Association of Human Rights

column8: Military Forces of Morocco (1999-) Auxiliary Forces

On 19 July 2019, following celebrations of the Algerian national team's victory in the African Cup of Nations, a group of people held a demonstration which led to some acts of sabotage and looting of property in Laayoune. Police forces intervened. Dozens of officers were injured and four of them sustained serious injuries. One civilian also died, although the cause of her death is unknown. Witnesses said that she was hit by an anti-riot police vehicle. According to Amnesty International, police forces used excessive force against demonstrators. Some news sources blamed Polisario for encouraging the violence. [size=around 9000 across 5 cities]
